p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the second report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 7 September, 14 September 2022, 28 September 2022 and 26 October
1. The committee resolved to present the following 172 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 173 petitions:
Infrastructure: Sport
For a Capital city, Canberra is embarrassingly lacking a facility to host large-scale live music events, sporting events, and social events.
Our UC Capitals are homeless and need a place to play.
An arena would be great for the local economy and will boost Canberra tourism.
We therefore ask the House to support the development of an arena in Canberra by pledging funding for the project.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4104)
Housing
Australia is suffering one of the worst housing crisis it has ever seen.
Thousands are being pushed into homelessness despite being able to pay rent.
Pension holders, single-parent families and those affected by the recent pandemic and floods are being left in a housing market that has zero accountability nor accessibility.

We therefore ask the House to act on this problem to increase Social-Housing funding, reinstate the NRAS to off-set increase housing costs for low-income families and take immediate action to resolve outdated laws that allow tenants to be locked from renewing a lease without grounds.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN4105)
COVID-19: Vaccine

As the world's only medicine and therapeutic regulatory entity that does not recognize WHO approved Sinopharm as a recognized Covid-19 vaccine for over 60s, it is necessary for TGA to regularly review this decision. The decision should not be lightly made and forgotten as it has significant and long-standing implications including blocking a large number of people who have strong ties with some Australian citizens and residents from entering Australia. Some of them have taken 3 doses of the vaccine which provide an acceptable level of protection against Covid-19 and they pose no risk to the community under Australia's current Covid situation. There are numerous Sinopharm trials inclusive of over 60s around the globe according to Vaccine Tracker and TGA seems to have neglected some recent trial results.

We therefore ask the House to urge TGA to review its decision of not recognizing Sinopharm for over 60s which was made urgently last year under insufficient considerations but has significant and long standing implications on the wellbeing of some Australian citizens and residents.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN4107)
COVID-19: Vaccine

As the world's only medicine and therapeutic regulatory entity that does not recognize WHO approved Sinopharm as a recognized Covid-19 vaccine for over 60s, it is necessary for TGA to regularly review this decision. The decision could not be lightly made and forgotten as it has significant and long-standing implications including blocking a large number of people who have strong ties with some Australian citizens and residents from entering Australia. Some of them have taken 3 doses of the vaccine which provide an acceptable level of protection against Covid-19 and they pose no risk to the community under Australia's current Covid situation. There are numerous Sinopharm trials inclusive of over 60s around the globe according to Vaccine Tracker and TGA seems to have neglected some recent trial results.

We therefore ask the House to urge TGA to review its decision of not recognizing Sinopharm for over 60s which was made urgently last year under insufficient considerations but has significant and long standing implications on the wellbeing of some Australian citizens and residents.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN4108)
Partner Visas

The Australian Partner visas (801, 820, 309, 100, subclass 300) are amongst the slowest and most cost prohibitive worldwide when compared to similar analogues and pathways. Whilst the risk of abuse of Partner visa pathways are ever present, punitive fees and policy merely causes undue harm to the average Australians and their loved ones. The federal governments record of ballooning fees and processing times should not be allowed to continue. Short of an overhaul to the Immigration process, changes to simplify processes and deescalate the cost and complexity of these visas outlined above, especially following the COVID pandemic, is worth heavy consideration. To do otherwise would be inhumane. The introduction of sponsor pre-approval has loomed overhead of prospective partner visas for several years and it is tone deaf to introduce them just as Australia's borders are finally opening and the cost of living is soaring.

We therefore ask the House to freeze or reduce the cost of the Australian partner visas listed above, consider any changes within the Houses power to reduce the wait times for application review and to scrap or alter the preapproval pathway as it outlined in 2021 before its introduction in the future.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4109)
Visual Arts Industry: Film

Australia needs to develop and fund more local films. Now that our international borders are open, we need to generate and activate more local creative talent for a global audience. The original 1997 film G.I. Jane is lacking a sequel. In the spirit of the 1987 US sitcom midday movie "The Facts of Life Down Under", and the US sitcom Modern Family which sees the loveable cast travel down under in 2014 for Season 5 Episode 20 "Australia", G.I. Jane 2 is ripe for filming. One location suggestion is to utilise the defence force training lands around Rockhampton and Mount Berserker as a plausible film plot segue. A Film Task Force is urgently required to support this creative endeavour.
We therefore ask the House to please establish a Film Task Force to develop and fund G.I. Jane 2
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4114)
Private Health Insurance

Taxation and other laws around private health insurance contain clauses where fully privately insured spouses are penalised by the Medicare levy surcharge as being uninsured because of their spouses' choice not to be insured. The government imposes an unfair penalty on a fully insured individual. These laws are particularly repugnant to individuals who may be in no position to compel the spouse to have private health insurance, as with domestic violence. A person must not be accountable and/or penalised for the choice of the spouse.
We therefore ask the House to amend or remove any laws where a fully privately health insured individual will be penalised by the Medicare levy surcharge for an uninsured spouse.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4118)
Skilled Migration Program

Sc491 and Sc494 visas are the 5 year visas anda pathway to permanent residency. Within these 5 years applicants work and live in regional Australia and contribute to the economy. Also in these years most of them are able to save deposit for the house but extra stamp duty payable in most of the states becomes a big hurdle in the immigrants dream of owning their own home. Not only this they lag behind in owning their own home due to the immense growth within that time. This step will not only help them but will also help regional Australia as most of them would settle down in regional due to the visa conditions imposed on them.

Sc 491 and Sc 494 visa holders should be considered as domestic students by universities and colleges. Many applicants and their dependents are keen for further studies and career progression However the sky high fee of universities does not let them do that and they lag behind again. By the time they get permanent residency they may have a young family, plans to save and buy house etc so they are not able to study again. So they should be considered as domestic fee paying students so that they can study further and in turn can help the country grow.
We therefore ask the House to equalise the stamp duty for permanent residents and Sc 491 visa holders for buying a house.
Consider them as domestic fee paying students for further education.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4119)
Ukraine

Ukraine needs assistance with equipment to continue to fight against the Russian invasion. On 31 March 2022, when addressing the Australian Parliament, the Ukrainian President Vlodomyr Zelensky, asked for Bushmaster vehicles from Australia.
We therefore ask the House to act to provide this assistance, in the form of the requested Bushmaster vehicles, to Ukraine.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4122)
Pensions and Benefits

Bringing back JobKeeper to flood affected regions would ensure the survival of the local economy, jobs and businesses. Whilst there is certain income support available, the currently available Disaster Recovery Allowance, which stands at just over $600 per fortnight, is woefully inadequate.
Many have no place of work left, whilst others have lost thousands of dollars through lack of infrastructure, and extreme weather preventing work from occurring.
The return of JobKeeper would not only allow businesses to remain operational and the local economy to rebuild, but would also allow certain trades leeway to provide flood relief work.
Flood affected regions needed help after the first floods, now this second round has made the situation dire for so many.
We therefore ask the House to bring back JobKeeper for, at a minimum, anyone eligible for the Disaster Recovery Allowance.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4125)
Pensions and Benefits

Non For Profit Homeless Support is often not available X7 days week. The current groups for example might advertise Food available Friday's. It is understandable that homelessness involves duty of care and that adequate Centrelink and non-discriminate housing for unemployed should be the better priority. However intermittently homelessness refuge is 24/7 7-days.

We therefore ask the House to consider legislation that supports financial independence even if employment and business ownership is not possible. That Centrelink should be legally banned from suspending clients—even if clients require financial support, financial advice / counselling, support workers, social workers, police and legal action. That NFP grant applicants may only be approved if providing food 7-days even if it is vouchers.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4130)
COVID-19: International Travel

The 'Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) Declaration 2020' will lapse on 17 April 2022. Despite the obvious absence of a biosecurity emergency, international travelers into and out of Australia will still be required to provide proof of double vaccination against COVID-19 beyond that date. To that effect, the Minister for Health has issued the 'Biosecurity (Exit Requirements) Determination 2022' and 'Biosecurity (Entry Requirements—Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) Amendment No.1 Determination 2022'. There is no scientific or any other rational justification for denying Australians who are not fully vaccinated against Covid the right to travel internationally, regardless of their reason for not being vaccinated against COVID-19. Maintaining these travel restrictions is inhumane and can only be seen as a continued attempt by the Federal Government to coerce those who remain unvaccinated to submit to COVID-19 vaccination, despite repeated assurances that such vaccination is voluntary.

We therefore ask the House to review the relevant determinations and ask the Federal Government to remove all remaining travel restrictions when the Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) Declaration 2020 lapses on 17 April 2022.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4135)
Health Care

Redlands has a chronic shortage of medical practitioners that is affecting the ability to access GPs. Changing the Commonwealth Government's Distribution Priority Area (DPA) classification for the Redlands will seek to address the chronic shortage of medical practitioners providing better healthcare services for our community.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Distribution Priority Area (DPA) classification for the Bowman electorate to allow for recruitment of more medical practitioners to serve the healthcare needs of our community.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4139)
Schools

The current cadet corps programme is inefficient in that it relies heavily on volunteers and is underfunded. A return to the programme that existed in schools and colleges and with serving defence force personnel as instructors would instill discipline and weapon safety in the students as well as provide a base for future involvement in the Defence Force.
We therefore ask the House to seriously consider reintroducing cadets into the school system and controlled by the Defence force, properly funded and with serving defence force instructors.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4143)
Environment

Over 230 years, we have significantly degraded our ancient lands and seas in the name of progress and now climate change is adding to the problems. It's time for a new paradigm for nature. This 10 point plan will see lands, seas, habitats and species protected, restored and managed sustainably for our future.
We therefore ask the House to support this plan for:
1. A new #fornature paradigm, incorporating Indigenous knowledge about caring for county.
2. A proactive, collaborative national plan to achieve zero emissions by 2050 or sooner.
3. An Environmental Protection Act that effectively protects vulnerable habitat and threatened species and stops development that's anti-nature.
4. A Significant increase in funding to protect and restore threatened species and habitat.
5. Initiate a major new program to restore and reforest marginal/degraded landscapes in order to capture carbon.
6. A major review of the Murray Darling Basin Plan to better manage scarce water resources, keep rivers flowing and sustain vulnerable habitats and fish stocks.
7.The rapid expansion of Regenerative Agriculture to improve our fragile soils, address salinity and erosion and transform land management.
8. A new National Plan to permanently protect 30% of Australia's land and seas in line with the UN Biodiversity Convention.
9. The phasing out of logging of native forest and expand plantation forestry to meet our timber needs.
10. Nation standards for the design of urban areas and new buildings to achieve net zero emissions, improve liveability and reduce heat effects.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4145)
Infrastructure: Building Standards

There needs to be some type of Government( Federal or State) assistance scheme to help with rectification of the cladding that the Government now been deemed illegal. This has now made our buildings uninsurable or insurance premiums for "High Risk" unsustainable.

We therefore ask the House to pass a bill to put in place a scheme to help fund the rectification of flammable cladding. This was a federal ruling so it should be a Federal responsibility to assist with the rectification & insurance fallout from the ruling.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4146)
Nuclear Energy
With fusion energy now routinely achieved around the world.
We now know Fusion produces no harmful emissions or waste fuel. A fusion power plant is physically incapable of having a meltdown. There is no fissile radioactive waste leftover.
Fusion fuel can be found in all fresh and seawater around the world and only half a bathtub of seawater is needed and will produce as much energy as 40 train cars of coal.
Countries that adopt fusion power will enable the creation of a new industry, with jobs, revenues, and leadership that goes with that.
Beyond the grid, fusion is well suited for remote and energy-intensive operations such as desalinization, industrial heat, and mining.

Even today, spin-offs from fusion research are keeping people healthy and safe. Technologies for advanced cancer treatment, medical isotopes, and next-generation national security scanners have already been deployed.
Fusion can also serve a vital role in space power and propulsion, dramatically expanding opportunities and reducing costs in space.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. We ask that the house initiate the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) milestones approach to start Australia down the path of setting up the regulatory framework needed for the nuclear fusion power industry development in Australia.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4147)
COVID-19: Vaccine

COVAX-19/Spikogen is a COVID-19 vaccine developed by a company in Adelaide called Vaxine. COVAX-19/Spikogen currently has authorisation for use in Iran. Yet Australians cannot easily access this homegrown vaccine yet because it hasn't been authorised yet by the TGA. Vaxine hasn't got big grants of Australian tax payer dollars in research funding. Despite having no government funded grants for their COVID-19 vaccine research the TGA told Vaxine to pay upwards of $300,000 just so that the TGA would look at the vaccine to consider provisionally approving it. Other vaccine company's that have dealt with the TGA have got some kind of research grant from various governments around the globe for their COVID-19 vaccines yet Vaxine got none and was still asked to pay the government to look at their vaccine. Unless the Australian government gives Vaxine a substantial monetary research grant then Vaxine should be able to have TGA application fees waived.

We therefore ask the House to make sure the TGA prioritises looking at moving vaxine's vaccine status from Provisional determination to Provisionally approved. As well as giving Vaxine a substantial research grant or the TGA waiving the application fee for the TGA to look at provisionally approving Vaxine's COVID-19 vaccine.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4149)
Climate Change

It's no doubt that Australia is a laggard when it comes to action on climate change, as represented by a lack of strong climate legislation. The recent IPCC report provides internationally recognised approaches to properly respond to Climate Change, and Australians request that we do our part to reduce our emissions and respond to climate change, especially as such a rich country.

Some examples where we underperform are the lack of leadership on removing massive fossil fuel subsidies and an eventual phase-out, implementing carbon prices and helping fund the alternatives. The prices and policies aren't right and the incentives for continual massive emissions, and slow climate change response, are too strong.

The secretary-general of the United Nations recently criticised Australia for our lack of action, and it pains to have not seen a major breakthrough Climate Change bill be presented, in the context of the knowledge that the IPCC reports present.

Our current government promotes a technology not taxes approach, which seriously underperforms potential action. When it is considered that not enough is being done to ensure that these technologies can actually be implemented, such as through lack of a fossil fuel phaseout, Australians demand action.

We therefore ask the House to introduce climate legislation that urgently implements the full solution recommendations made by IPCC into law, to ensure that Australia has a prosperous future in the low-carbon economy.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4156)
Mental Health

Forensic psychological interventions aimed at preventing criminal behaviours (particularly for at risk youth), rehabilitating offenders and improving community safety should be provided through the public health system (Medicare). People who engage in offending behaviours (e.g. drug offences, stealing offences, violence, domestic violence and problematic sexual behaviours), often have complex mental health issues that are interconnected with their behaviours. Compared to the general population, they often have higher rates of homelessness, disabilities, mental health issues, substance addictions, unemployment and financial hardship. This creates a barrier to accessing effective treatments as they are less able to pay privately. Expanding the Medicare system to cover forensic psychological interventions would ensure less people fall through the gaps and allow greater access to specialist interventions for those at risk of offending, improving our overall community safety.

In Australia, as in many other countries, the prison population has disproportionately high rates of people who are indigenous, people from ethnic minorities, people with mental health issues, people with disabilities, people from low socioeconomic backgrounds, and people with complex trauma histories. These rates show that offending behaviours are more complex than just people being 'bad', and that crime should be considered a public health issue. A huge amount of taxpayer money is spent on policing, court processes, incarceration, parole/bail supervision and treatment/compensation of victims of crime. By investing money into treatments aimed at rehabilitation and preventing offending, we can reduce this financial burden on the government.
We therefore ask the House to include forensic psychological interventions under Medicare.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4157)
Housing

Provide home ownership options for people with disabilities and their carers who are unable to work due to no fault of their own. Key-starts shared access base loan approves $290,000 purchase price on government pension alone. If a first home owners grant that we have seen in prior years, was offered to our most vulnerable, it would increase their purchasing options. As a result it would free up community housing, and also save the government long term, by no longer paying rent assistance.
$145.80 per fortnight over 40 years is $151,923 vs a one off $50,000 home ownership grant.

We therefore ask the House to consider creating an "Access First Home owners Grant" of $50,000 directed towards people with disabilities, or their immediate carers who are dependent on disability and carers pensions for life due to no fault of their own.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4158)
COVID-19: Vaccine
As leaders of our great country they need to stand up and have our best interests in the forefront, before declaring a safe and effective vaccine, they can prove it is.

We therefore ask the House to make all new Covid-19 vaccines compulsory for all members of parliament for testing before testing on any members of public, or lose your membership for parliament permanently.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4159)
Food Labelling

In Australia the rate of obesity is on the rise. A way to combat this, is to make it mandatory for food companies to state the exact amount of food that a 'serving size' is on the nutritional label, to make understanding appropriate portions easier for the consumer e.g 4 biscuits, 3/4 cup rice puffs. This will make it easier for the consumer to understand the energy and nutrients that are in the food item they are consuming and how much of that food is an appropriate portion. The importance of having an easy to understand nutritional information labelling, including serving sizes, is imperative for consumer awareness and understanding of their food purchasing and in guiding them toward informed food choices and portion size selection. Thus reducing overall calorie consumption which may assist in body weight management.

We therefore ask the House to make it mandatory for food companies to state the amount of food a serving size is on the nutritional label using common measurements appropriate to the food e.g 4 biscuits, 3/4 cup rice puffs.
from 177 citizens (Petition No. EN4163)
Tertiary Education

Most students get into mountains of debt when studying, not just because of the cost of doing the courses but also the amount of hours done during placement that go unpaid. Placement hours do vary from course to course but most are 30-36 hours a week 5 days a week, meaning they are then unable to get a full time, part time or casual job in-between to actually get an income. Students have to not only pay for the course but they also have to pay for transport, their meals every day, rent, the list goes on. Not to mention the amount of hours being done unpaid has been proven to affect those trainees negatively with regards to their mental and physical health. With the rising cost of everything as well students are being screwed over in this regard, they need support.
We therefore ask the House to create a supporting payment for people doing unpaid placement to help them through the tough financial times they go through for the hard work they put in.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN4166)
Political Advertising
Prevent lies and false information from being advertised by politicians and affiliates especially during political campaigns.
We have put up with this from all parties for too long. If this behaviour was undertaken outside of the political stream it would be illegal and classified as false advertising or deformation.
We therefore ask the House to make it a criminal offence to provide false or misleading information to the public in order to gain advantage.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4167)
Illicit Drugs: Cannabis

I am not happy about having to break a law to be able to partake in the use of cannabis. I need it's beneficial medicinal properties and myself and many others that I have spoken to do not understand how it is still not legal in Australia. American law has overtaken ours in the laws that govern marijuana cultivation and use. We need to legalise or decriminalise marijuana/ cannabis recreational use for adults in this country. I can't believe America is ahead of the ball with this

We therefore ask the House to immediately legalise the recreational use of marijuana / cannabis for adults as well as the cultivation and other forms of processing of cannabis products. We ask that the practice be at least decriminalised for adult recreational and medical uses
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN4168)
COVID-19: Vaccine
Fully vaccinated Immunocompromised patients don't produce antibodies and remain vulnerable to COVid infection.
AstraZeneca have produced a monoclonal antibody injection that will give us 6 months protection from infection and a return to society.
We therefore ask the House to secure sufficient Evulsheld to protect all immunocompromised Australians so we can safely return to a productive life .
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4169)
Temporary Visas
Bridging visa b applicants have been subject to unfair and significantly delayed processing times, causing financial loss and mental distress.
Many of these applicants had their plans delayed even though applications were submitted well ahead of expected date of travel.

Promptly processing bridging visa b will allow applicants to be able to prevent financial loss from flight tickets and travel plans cancellations, and alleviate unnecessary stress for those especially with loved ones abroad to visit due to personal or medical reasons.

We therefore ask the House to review the processing time for bridiging visa b; ensure application processing times are clearly communicated in either real-time or periodically; and reduce bridging visa b application processing time to at most 10 business days.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4177)
Diesel

There is no good reason for the price of diesel to be sold at an excessive price, it is just the major corporations slogging Australians to make themselves extra money. The price of unleaded has dropped significantly with the price of diesel barely dropping in price.
This is an unnecessary financial stress on those who have vehicles that run on diesel.
We therefore ask the House to forcibly lower the price of diesel fuel to better match the price of unleaded fuel.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4179)
Telecommunications

4G/5G Mobile Phone Base Stations emit Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Fields (RF-EMFs) in the microwave range, classified as a Group 2B carcinogen by the IARC, the specialized cancer agency of the WHO.

Because of the technical nature of these cell towers, town councils oftentimes don't have the necessary in-house expertise to evaluate the development applications, relying on technical reports prepared by consultants. These consultants are hired by the carriers (e.g. Optus), which makes their reports potentially biased in favour of installing these cell towers.

Several studies have found that people don't want to live near or buy a property located next to mobile phone base stations and that immediate adjacent properties suffer property value degradation of about 45%.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Ban the installation of mobile phone base stations on any residential or rural residential lots;
2. Specify penalties: "any false, misleading information or omissions regarding affected properties in the ARPANSA EME report will face fines of up to $50 million."
3. Changes to Deployment Code 564:2020:
a) Clause 6 Title change: Consultation Requirements for installation at a new site "with or" without development application .
b) Add additional subclause 3.2.4 to Time Frames:

Where a Carrier has identified a Neighbour, or an Interested and Affected Party as living overseas, living out of state, or not currently residing in the affected property, it must have regard to that fact and show proof that they have made every effort to contact the Party, and adjust time frames to consultation and notification accordingly.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4182)
Immigration Detention

This is the second petition on this matter. The response by the DOHA Detainees to the first petition was factually false and completely deceitful. Detainees at the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation are denied a working computer system upon which to prepare their legal cases. The computer system does not function at anywhere near a minimum standard and continually crashes and freezes. It is impossible for detainees to research or to do any work on the system thus deprives them of their legal right, and Serco's contractual condition, to be able to prepare and defend themselves in a court of law.

We therefore ask the House to once again, seek reasons and then address, why Serco have received a $2.55 billion dollar contract to manage the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation yet are unable to provide those detainees with access to a functioning computer system for legal documents and research. It is a breach of international law and detainee Human Rights that they are denied their right to prepare and defend themselves in a court of law.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4186)
Immigration Detention

This is a second petition on the same matter. Serco staff continue, despite the DOHA making it clear the practice must stop, to allow detainees use the toaster to light, then sit and smoke cigarettes within the common room, living areas and cooking region. No attempt is made to stop the practice—instead Serco staff issue detainees the toaster to encourage the practice. Non-smoking detainees, many with health issues, are then forced to inhale cigarette smoke and further, should they wish to make toast, use a toaster full of cigarette ash to do so.

We therefore ask the House to ensure DOHA stops this practice ends immediately. There is a cigarette lighter external to the building, less than 20 metres from the door, that is for the lighting of cigarettes. It is nothing but sheer laziness that Serco staff give the toaster to detainees to allow them to continue this practice and then fail to enforce smoking bans inside the compounds.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4187)
Health Care

The Infant Nutrition Council is awarding an Agricultural Trade and Market Access Cooperation (ATMAC) grant for the purpose of helping the industry focus on expanding infant formula and toddler milk drink into markets into South-East Asia, Latin America and Middle East.
The Lactation Consultants of Australia and New Zealand (LCANZ) who support increasing breastfeeding rates in Australia and New Zealand, are extremely disappointed and deeply concerned by this news.

The Australian Government National Breastfeeding Strategy acknowledges that increasing breastfeeding rates in Australia is of vital importance. The strategy has not been implemented. Currently Australia ranks third last out of 98 countries in the latest World Breastfeeding Trends Initiative, meeting only 25.5 out of 150 of the breastfeeding support/promotion criteria.
The marketing of infant formula undermines breastfeeding rates, and it is our belief that it does not require promotion.

We therefore ask the House to support the request that the Agricultural Trade and Market Access Cooperation (ATMAC) funding /grant be rescinded or redirected to implement The Australian Government National Breastfeeding Strategy and support breastfeeding families.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN4188)
Veterans

The Administrate Appeals Tribunal (AAT) has delegated legislation by way of the "person giving expert or opinion evidence guideline" (guide). The guide applies to parties before the AAT, and ensures natural justice prevails....

An anomaly exists in that information adduced by persons giving expert or opinion evidence in matters before the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission, the Repatriation Commission (Commissions) and the Veterans Review Board (Board) to do so, in a manner which does not conform to that of the AAT guide....
This double standard disadvantages Veteran claimants and applicants, and result in them having to unnecessarily appeal a matter to the AAT to receive natural justice....

It is widely acknowledged that appealing a matter to the AAT is a complex and stressful process, not the least because the Commissions can engage legal representation. It is also a needless burden to the Commonwealth purse and resources of the Commission, Board and AAT....

This anomaly can be overcome if the VEA were amended in such a way which would require persons giving expert or opinion evidence in a matter before the Commissions and Board, to do so from the onset in a manner which conformed to the AAT guide.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes that will cause such an amendment to the Veterans Acts as to result in persons giving expert or opinion evidence in matters before the Commissions and Board, to do so in a manner which aligns with the AAT guide.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4196)
Workplace Relations

Hardworking taxpayers who are pet owners/pet parents do not have the same rights to take personal carer's leave and compassionate or bereavement leave to care, provide support, or grieve for their loved pet.

A pets mere presence can provide companionship, reduce loneliness, depression and anxiety. They become a significant vital source of support. Additionally for the 1/4 Australian women who will never have children, pets are not just important, they can be integral to physical and mental wellbeing.
The death of a pet can be a devastating life-altering loss that impacts mental and physical wellbeing, and productivity at work.
Grief is grief, bosses should not be able to decide what kind of grief is valid, and what isn't.

We therefore ask the House to include pets under the definition of "immediate family member" or a "member of the household" under the Fair Work Act 2009 to allow employees access to personal carer's leave, and compassionate/bereavement leave following the death of a pet.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4198)
Migration

With Australia being a sought after country for immigrants to migrate to and the need for overseas skilled labour. It is not a surprise the Department of Home Affairs (DoHA) are inundated in visa applications.

We feel there is a need for transparency and clear communication to come from DoHA, the anguish and mental burden on timeframes should be considered. noting the following timelines (as of 5th May 2022 update for the DoHA website):
186 visas—4-25 months
190 visa—4-10 months
482 visa—1-15 months.
The timeframes are vast and no tracking or contact is available.
Having researched similar visa types from around the world and note the following finding's:
UK, 6months, but will endeavour to complete before this time most being complete within 8 weeks (and do offer a fast track options)
Germany, 2-3 weeks.
Canada, 94 days. but offer tracking of applications.
New Zealand, 50% 76 days 90% 6 months.
Note most countries have a point of contact or tracking and accountability.

Also consideration for the transition route, the route is there to provide temporary visa holders a route to residency, note this is the most lengthy process! Surly with proven work history, sponsorship and in Country experience, this should be the shortest path?
Note visa costs are circa $5k per person, application only.
We therefore ask the House to
Consider a reform / audit on the visa process? Ensure timeframes are realistic and maintained.
Provide transparency on visa timeframe and processing.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4200)
Personal Information and Privacy

Outing is the act of revealing an LGBT person's sexual orientation or gender identity without that person's consent. Schools, workforces and other like organisations should be prohibited from outing LGBT Youth as a part of their duty of care towards those youth.

If a child has not disclosed their identity to their caretaker already, it is likely that doing so will result in direct harm to the child physically or mentally. It puts children at risk of being kicked out, disowned, stressed or abused.

In medical settings, youths are already protected under duty of confidentiality. If minors can consent to their medical information being shared, they should be able to consent to their identity-related information being shared.
We therefore ask the House to create a bill or policy preventing the outing of queer youth.
from 195 citizens (Petition No. EN4201)

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Overseas Visitor Health Cover

p.span: Private Health Insurance: Overseas Visitor Health Cover
Australians has very limited options to opt for Overseas Visitors Health Cover (OVHC) for their parents and relatives.
As of now, Australians have one provider to opt for the 70 years and above and only 2 companies are holding the monopoly of 8501 condition Overseas Visitors Health Cover (OVHC).

Recently the premiums has been hiked and it is becoming a expensive options if Australians have aged parents and other 600 stream visa holders with 8501 condition Health Insurance and they are forced to opt for expensive 'Overseas Visitors Health Cover(OVHC)'.
Australian government must look into this monopolised market and lessen the burden of the Australians who oblige to the '8501—Health Insurance' Visa conditions for their parents and other visitors.
We therefore ask the House to end this monopoly and provided the cheaper alternatives for '8501—Health Insurance' for Visitor Visas.
Thank you.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4202)
World Health Organization

We want the government to commit to not signing any international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organisation (WHO), unless this is approved through public referendum.

The WHO is currently preparing an international agreement on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response. We believe the public must be fully informed about any such treaty, with a public copy of this treaty available to study, and that the public should ultimately decide on whether to commit to it.
We therefore ask the House to commit to releasing to the public any Pandemic Treaty in full to the public and put the choice to commit to such a treaty to a referendum.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4203)
Political Advertising

Paul Fletcher MP—Minister for Communications' response (MS21-002610) to EN3329, EN3264, EN3288, EN3296, EN3328 provided no solution to the amended of Acts for the sole reason these petitions were created.

The people of Australia are all for "Freedom of Expression" and "Freedom of Political Expression" however this should come with some limitations, especially unsolicited text messages (like those from a certain UAP member & other parties)
If us Australians don't want Political text messages & emails, we deserve the opportunity to Stop or limit them. This is our Freedom of Expression that we are not currently given!
We therefore ask the House to amend the Spam Act 2003 to include "Political" in wording along with Commercial to mandate unsubscribe options in electronic unsolicited messaging.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4204)
Veterans

Despite the VEA referencing, "evidence" and "oath or affirmation" in Sections 32, 128 and 151, the respondents legal representative in Shafran and Secretary DVA and other, WAD 262/2020, in defining the term "evidence" stated. "And of course, the ordinary meaning of the word is also relevant, and I've already noted our reference to the Collins Dictionary reference, which includes anything that you can see, experience, read or are told that causes you to believe that something is true or has really happened. So it has meaning in common usage. It's not limited to the judicial meaning of evidence taken under oath or affirmation"….

The Collins definition is unreasonable, and in tension with the VEA, which requires the Repatriation Commission(Commission) and Veterans' Review Board(Board) to provide reasons for decision that refer to, "evidence" or "other material"….

If "evidence" is defined as per the Collins, …"which includes anything"…, a reasonable question can be asked as to what constitutes "other material". Further, s137(1)(a) references "evidence" and s138(2)(b) "other material" in how information is independently provided to the Board….

Veterans and decision makers deserve greater clarity, and noting decisions of the Commission and Board can be appealed to the AAT and Federal Court, the Collins definition is arguably not fit for purpose.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes that will cause such an amendment to the VEA that will provide a reasonable, refined and fit for purpose definition of "evidence" that aligns with "the judicial meaning" for use within the VEA.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4205)
Climate Change

The transport sector accounts for about one-fifth of Australia's carbon emissions and is a major contributor to global warming. In every OECD country, except Russia, governments have set standards for CO2 emissions. The kiwis have launched their decisive "Clean Car Standards". To help save the planet, Australia must follow suit.

Compared to other countries, Australia's transport is energy intensive. With the current policy settings, emissions reductions in this sector will fall far short of our 2030 targets. Many vehicles remain in service for over 20 years and our take up of EVs is extremely slow.

The new government must legislate standards for maximum CO2 emissions from new vehicles across the fleet for each carmaker. Regulated emission standards are not subsidies; they will not "destroy the weekend". They will encourage importers to introduce a broader range of EVs, hybrids and other technologies, giving consumers greater choice and an economic incentive to reduce emissions. EVs are much cheaper to run and maintain. They also provide public health benefits through less air and noise pollution.

Other incentives and programs to encourage low emission vehicles are welcome but this is the policy that will have the greatest effect, without the need for taxpayer subsidies. It will signal Australia's commitment to an effective long-term plan. It is a no-brainer!
We need action now for the sake of our grandchildren.
We therefore ask the House to legislate mandatory CO2 vehicle emissions standards, similar to the European standards, to come into effect before 2023.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4208)
Rural and Regional Health Services
* Our hospitals and health staff are at breaking point
* Our health professionals are delivering care 24 hours a day and 7 days a week within facilities that do not meet clinical need and are no longer fit for purpose

* Our community campaign seeks to deliver a clear message to the Federal Government that it needs to work with State Governments in NSW and Victoria to commit the money needed to deliver a purpose-built, state-of-the-art, single site hospital to deliver care to residents of Albury, Wodonga, north east Victoria and southern NSW.

We therefore ask the House to ensure the Federal Government will work with the Victorian and NSW Governments to set aside sufficient funding in the 2023-24 Federal Budget or earlier to plan, design and complete construction of a new single site regional public hospital for Albury-Wodonga.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4211)
Sri Lanka
We learn from social media that Yoshitha Rajapakse, a son of the deposed Prime Minister of Sri Lanka has allegedly travelled to Melbourne with proceeds of corruption.

Many prominent citizens of Sri Lanka and media are on record alleging that the source of funds transferred/to be transferred have been obtained through serious corruption linked to the misappropriation of public assets of Sri Lanka.

Yoshitha was the Chief of Staff of the ex-Prime Minister of Sri Lanka and allegedly a co-conspirator to the violence that is currently taking place in Sri Lanka. We believe that his family and politically exposed persons connected to him are involved in the transfer of such ill-gotten wealth from Sri Lanka to Australia.
We, as Australian Citizens, are deeply concerned that allowing such funds into Australia could also result in the proliferation of corrupt practices in our society.

We therefore ask the House to have this individual and any others linked to this corruption to be designated under the Autonomous Sanctions Amendment Regulations 2021 and intervene in the transfer of illegal funds to Australia.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4213)
World Health Organization
The WHO is currently preparing an international agreement on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response.

We believe the public must be furnished with the full ramifications of what and how any pandemic treaty could affect them, and be given a public vote on whether Australia should sign up, before the Australian Government signs up to this.
We therefore ask the House to establish a public referendum before signing any international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization (WHO)
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4216)
World Health Organization

Sovereign nations are about to become subject to the World Health Organisation if their representatives agree to this globalist push for centralised control of pandemic declaration and response. Shutdowns and vaccine mandates etc would be at the whim of the head of this globalist organisation.
We therefore ask the House to instruct the Australian representatives to the upcoming WHO meeting to vote AGAINST losing Australian sovereignty to this undemocratic globalist proposal.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4218)
World Health Organization

Our rights and national sovereignty are about to be handed over to The World Health Organization (WHO) in an unprecedented way at the next World Health Assembly meeting in Geneva, Switzerland next week, May 22 to 28, 2022.
Earlier this year, the United States Department of Health and Human Services, proposed several far-reaching amendments to the 2005 'International Health Regulations' that will be voted on next week.
Visible trends in the proposed amendments.
1. In the case that provisions were added, they always gave the WHO—and in particular General-Director—substantial additional powers.
2. In the case that provisions were scrapped, these always regarded safeguards to State Parties' rights to take their own decisions.
In short: national sovereignty everywhere around the world is under attack by these amendments.
So what now?
Send a clear message to our government that we will not be ruled by non-elected bodies with established conflicts of interest. sign. share. stay informed.
(details thanks to Eva Vlaardingerbroek's substack and World Council for Health).

We therefore ask the House to commit to not signing any ammendment to the international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization (WHO), unless it is approved through a public referendum.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4220)
World Health Organization

The WHO is currently preparing an international agreement on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response and expects global governments to agree to this without consultation of it's citizens. We, the people, have the right to be consulted on this and how any pandemic treaty could affect them and be given a vote on whether Australia should sign this treaty.
We therefore ask the House to commit to not signing any international treaty with the WHO unless this is approved through a public referendum.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4224)
World Health Organization

We want the Government to commit to not signing any international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization (WHO), unless this is approved through a public referendum.
The WHO is currently preparing an international agreement on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response.

We believe the public must be furnished with the full ramifications of what and how any pandemic treaty could affect them, and be given a public vote on whether the Australia should sign up or not, before the Australian Government signs up to this.

We therefore ask the House to seek the Australian peoples decision via a referendum on Australia signing onto any international treaty or similiar on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4225)
World Health Organization

Due to the Covid 19 pandemic, at 22-26 May 2022, 194 member nations of the World Health Organisation will vote whether to grant the WHO future authority over management and coordination of public health emergencies.
Australia and the Australian Parliament (including Liberal, Labor and National party members) have indicated their support as a potential signatory of this treaty.
Legislation has been prepared in anticipation of a vote of support.
We the citizens of Australia therefore submit this petition to Parliament on these bases:
- Australians have not been given a say. We have been denied the option of whether to accept or decline this treaty and its ramifications.
- The WHO is an unelected and unaccountable organisation which does not concern itself with the rights of citizens.
- Any such treaty or legal agreement with the WHO cedes sovereignty and the democratic right to self determination of the Australian people.
- This agreement also over-rides state and federal laws and is unlimited in its scope for forced medical procedures, detainment and enforcement by external agencies.
- If this treaty is formally ratified, Australians will have no right of reply or access to procedural fairness in the event of foreign intervention and
it will be extremely difficult to rescind or negotiate around in future.
We therefore ask the House to
- Immediately withdraw Australia from this proposed treaty.
- Cease and desist from signing any such proposal.
-Submit this treaty to the people to decide upon by referendum if it is deemed necessary to proceed with.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN4229)
World Health Organization
We deserve to keep our sovereign rights and not give them over to the WHO if and when we sign the Pandemic Treaty.
Our Government works for us and has no rights to give up our rights without a referendum of the people.
The WHO does not have a good record during global pandemics, with the H1N1 and Covid-19 proof they have not managed the last two worldwide pandemics well at all.

The WEF and WHO work together and have openly stated they approve of the way China has "controlled" their people during the pandemic. We have seen glimpses of this from our state leaders during the lockdowns and police brutality in Australia.
The WHO will have access to the UN to enforce their policys that they see fit to.

The Australian Government cannot allow foreign interests control the outcome of Australia. The people of Australia need to be told if the Pandemic Treaty allows the WHO full access to over rule the laws of Australia.

We therefore ask the House to put a hold to the approval of signing the WHO Pandemic Treaty until full disclosure has been made to the people on the outcomes which can occur during a pandemic called by the WHO if we sign the treaty. Not just the pretty outcomes our current PM Scott Morrison has dropped on the Australia public at a press conference in Darwin. Once full disclosure has been made, the people of Australia have the opportunity to vote on the outcomes.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4230)
World Health Organization

We want the Government to commit to not signing any international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization (WHO), unless this is approved through a public referendum.
The WHO is currently preparing an international agreement on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response.

We believe the public must be furnished with the full ramifications of what and how any pandemic treaty could affect them, and be given a public vote on whether Australia should sign up, before the Australian Government signs up to this.
We therefore ask the House to not sign any WHO Pandemic Treaty unless it is approved via public referendum
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4232)
World Health Organization

We ask the Government to commit to not signing any international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization (WHO) unless this is approved through a public referendum.

Australia must not sign away our sovereignty on health care. But that is exactly what some Australian leaders are trying to do, and there is tremendous pressure from around the world to make us do it.

The treaty includes 190 countries and would be legally binding. It defines and classifies what is considered a pandemic and would give the W.H.O. legal power over Australia's pandemic response, including the ability to force lockdowns and dictate which drugs or vaccines can be used. If a pandemic is declared, the WHO takes over the global health management of the pandemic.

We therefore ask the House to protect the health and safety of its own citizens, and maintain our sovereignty from international and private influences; we call upon the Prime Minister and all Members of Parliament to:
-Ensure that Australia retains its healthcare sovereignty
-Ensure the unelected WHO bureaucrats do not wield decision-making power over Australia's pandemic response
-Decline to sign the WHO Pandemic Treaty.
We further call upon the Prime Minister to:
-Call a review of Australia's COVID-19 response, develop our own national pandemic strategy, and invest in our own healthcare system.
We say NO to the WHO pandemic treaty!
Health needs freedom, democracy, and self-determination.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4233)
World Health Organization

We want the Government to commit to not signing any international treaty on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organization (WHO), unless this is approved through a public referendum and all details of the treaty are fully disclosed to the public with full transparency. Handing over our sovereign rights that overrule our constitution constitutes as Treason. We are a sovereign country and should decide who our public servant are.

We therefore ask the House to disclose to the public the full details of the treaty and hold a referendum for the people to vote. The public must know how it will impact the people of Australia, what the WHO can or can't do and what rights can be taken away in the event of a pandemic so that the people can decide and vote.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4236)

subdebateinfo.title: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action

p.span: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action

In 2019, 12 countries signed the Intergovernmental Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action for which UNICEF, YOUNGO and the Children's Environmental Rights Initiative are the joint custodians, but Australia still has not signed the Declaration. As Earth goes into climate emergency whilst we embark on the UN Decade on Ecosystem Regeneration to resuscitate her, it is ever more urgent and more critical for the first generation to feel the effect of climate change and the last generation who can do something about it, to be united to avoid intragenerational confrontations. Therefore, it is imperative for the government to recognise and mobilise the enormous capacity of children and youth to be mighty agents of change by consistently considering the latter's specific needs, rights, and perspectives in climate actions at all levels. The Declaration represents an opportunity for Australia to commit to the adoption of a comprehensive framework to rectify the widespread omission of children and youth from climate policies across different tiers of government. We have already squandered 30 years, there is simply no more time for mankind to be divided and conquered by this climate crisis due to infighting between younger and older members of this last generation who can ensure the survival of our future generations. Let's put our Earth where our mouth is!

We therefore ask the House to debate and vote on a motion urging the executive government to sign the Intergovernmental Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action by 12/8/22, or 26/10/22 at the latest.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4242)
Banking and Financial Services
Private research shows regional Australia has lost 62 per cent of its banks since 1975, leaving just 1062 located mainly in clusters in larger centres.

The number of towns and cities with a bank has shrunk from 1226 to 386: 575 towns that once had one or more major banks now have no form of bank at all. Another 146 towns are on the brink of complete loss of banking services, with just one major bank open.

Last year, regional Australia lost 113 "big four" bank branches. Locations included 45 towns that were stripped of their last/only bank. Of these, 23 did not have a minor corporate, mutual or franchise bank to fall back on.
If a similar 10 per cent cut to the branch network is made this year, 100 more branches will be lost in the next seven months: 50 towns will lose their last bank.

This issue has not been looked at properly for 17 years. The Morrison Government set up a "taskforce into regional banking" as a pre-election stunt but only put representatives of the banking industry and its own politicians on it. Just one public meeting was held. Findings have not yet been delivered.

We therefore ask the House to impose an immediate moratorium on regional bank closures, launch a new inquiry to pick up from where Money too Far Away (1999) and Money Matters in the Bush (2004) left matters and pulp any reports that come from the coalition's taskforce.
from 4,946 citizens (Petition No. EN4244)
Taxation

Many aged care and disability support workers use a Meal Entertainment Card in their salary packaging arrangements. The ATO says this increases their take-home wages by decreasing the tax they pay as it increases their tax free threshold. Those cards can only be used to pay for meals at cafes and restaurants. The salary packaging amount allowed to go on those cards was almost unlimited in the past, but now it is limited to just $2,650 per FBT year. To help boost customers at cafes and restaurants, and to effectively help boost the wages of aged care and disability support workers, please double their Meal Entertainment Card salary packaging maximum limit to $5,300 per FBT year. Calculated per week, if they choose that new higher limit, that would equate to four meals per week they can buy for their families using that Meal Entertainment Card in their local communities. This benefit will quickly increase the number of customers visiting cafes and restaurants, while also increasing the money-multiplier effect directly within those local communities.
We therefore ask the House to double the Meal Entertainment Card salary packaging maximum limit to $5,300 per FBT year for aged care and disability support workers
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4246)
Medicare
EVERY AUSTRALIAN MUST PAY THEIR MEIDCARE LEVY (EXCEPT THE AGED PENSIONERS & AUST STUDENTS)
We therefore ask the House to MANDATE EVERY AUSTRALIAN PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY!
NO PERSON SHOULD BE ALLOWED FREE MEDICAL CARE PAID BY OTHERS
(EXCEPT AGED PENSIONERS & AUST. STUDENTS)
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4248)
World Health Organization

The World Health Assembly agreed to kickstart a global process last year to draft and negotiate an agreement under the Constitution of the WHO to strengthen pandemic prevention, preparedness and response.

We want the Australian Government to commit to not signing any international treaties on pandemic prevention and preparedness established by the World Health Organisation (WHO), unless they are approved through a public referendum first.

We robustly believe that the public must be furnished with the full ramifications of what and how any WHO pandemic treaty could affect them, and be given a fair public vote on whether Australian citizens should sign up, before the Australian Government signs up to this.
We therefore ask the House to not sign any WHO pandemic treaties unless it is approved via a referendum of the public first.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN4255)
Skilled Migration Program
Skilled migrant 489 visa holders are subject to live, work and study in certain regional postcodes, based on the date their visas were granted.

There were harsher limitations to prior visa holders, restricting them to smaller areas, in Queensland, for example, where a postcode as small as 4211, is literally impossible to find a place of study and work, if one resides here. This leaves the only viable option of a 49 minute drive twice a day to the next state to work, which is unaffordable with the costs of fuel at this present time. There is no other option open, due to the limitations in postcodes in the Queensland area for this visa granted before November 2019. This causes undue hardship on visa holders, and negatively impacts on mental health, work and family life.
The unbearable mental strain on some families has caused break ups in family situations and loss of sense of self.
It is particularly difficult as the wait for the 887 bridging visa is also near a two year wait.

We therefore ask the House to open up the same regional postcodes to work, live and study for all 489 visa holders, in order to have the same rights as those visa holders who were granted access to these extra postcodes after November 2019, in order to improve the quality of life for all 489 skilled visa migrants, while we wait for our 887 bridging visas.
We ask this humbly, and respectfully, and graciously.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN4256)
Media

The gradual concentration of media ownership within our three traditional media mediums of Newspapers, Radio and Television, has resulted in a substantial decrease in the quality and accuracy of information Australians receive in the form of news and opinion. The line between genuinely balanced news/current affairs and misinformation/entertainment, has been blurred to the detriment of our society. During the election campaign this has clearly been the case, especially with all the Murdoch owned assets. But there are others. The current structure and lack of diversity, creates unnecessary angst and divisiveness in the formation of public opinion. All Australians deserve access to the same timely, accurate and unbiased news allowing public opinion to be formed on facts and fact based argument, as opposed to misinformation and in some cases, partisanship and outright lies. A fully funded National Broadcaster operating under a strict mandate, should be seen as the industry benchmark for accurate, balanced and timely reporting.
We therefore ask the House to consider legislation to:
1) Limit foreign ownership of Australian media assets to 15% and banning access to any board seats.
2) Reintroduce Cross Media Ownership Restrictions limiting ownership to only one of the three traditional mediums.
3) Limit National population Reach for any individual asset to 75% for TV & Radio. Limit state and territory Reach to 40% for Newspapers within each individual state and territory.
4) The industry as a whole should be made to contribute to the annual funding of our National Broadcaster, the ABC.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4258)
Taxation

The Board of Taxation delivered to the Government in March 2019 their recommendations after a review of the individual tax residency rules. Whilst we agree with the spirit of the recommendations in that it provides more certainty for Australian citizens living overseas compared to the existing tax residency rules, some of the recommendations do lead to a inequitable treatment of Australians living overseas who reside in a country that does not have a Double Tax Agreement (DTA) with Australia and who do not have the protection of a tie breaker clause.

We therefore ask the House to take into account the inequitable outcome for those Australians who do not have the protection of a double taxation agreement when drafting the bill and implement the following: 1. A scoring or points system needs to be applied to the Factor Test in order to appropriately weight a persons ties to Australia 2. The proposed 45-day rule needs to be amended to 90 days in line with other countries as too many individuals may be categorised as tax residents without any enduring connection to Australia when visiting friends and family. 3. Provision and/or exclusions to be made during times of war or a pandemic when people are displaced. 4. Provision and/or exclusions to be made for travel to Australia as a result of family sickness or work/business travel. 5. Exclusions to be made for Australian citizen children returning to Australia to attend boarding school under the family factor test.
from 5,235 citizens (Petition No. EN4259)
Immigration Detention

The prolonged detention of asylum seekers and refugees is contrary to Article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, inflicted due to seeking protection from Australia, being inflicted because of seeking to exercise the right under Article 14 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to seek protection. The indefinite prolonged detention is torture and cruel punishment for seeking asylum in Australia by boat, designed to deter people from coming to Australia, and is torture under the United Nations Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. There was no consideration of alternatives to detention and this prolonged detention is in breach of article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The imposition of intolerable conditions and duration of detention, including unsafe conditions of detention, has had severe impacts on the asylum seekers and refugees physical and mental health. There have been deaths in detention, and there are asylum seekers and refugees who have irrevocable damage to their health from Australia's asylum seeker policy.

Australia's asylum seeker policy ((The Migration Legislation Amendment (Offshore Processing and Other Measures) Bill 2011, Migration Amendment (Unauthorised Maritime Arrivals and Other Measures) Act 2013 (Cth), Migration Legislation Amendment (Regional Processing and Other Measures) Act 2012 (Cth) s 25)) must change to include compassion and to respect and protect human rights.
We therefore ask the House to change Australia's asylum seeker policy, to end this torture and cruel punishment for people seeking asylum in Australia by boat.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4260)
World Health Organization
On 27 May 2022 Australia signed the World Health Organization (WHO) Pandemic Treaty.

This treaty proposes to give power to unelected, Tedros Ghebreyesus, Ethiopian public health researcher/Director-General of the corporation- World Health Organization (WHO) who can call a pandemic and override OUR constitution. Even worse the Government and the media have been silent at alerting the public to the horror of the global governance they are attempting to implement.

We therefore ask the House to reject any amendments to the 2005 W.H.O. International Health Regulations, any future amendments and any steps towards the International Pandemic Treaty or any such treaties. No referendum was held.
WE AUSTRALIANS DO NOT WANT TO BE A PART OF THE W.H.O. PANDEMIC TREATY.
Start to take steps to remove the corporation—WHO from Australia.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN4266)
Family Law
The Child Support System is outdated and not based Fairly. It is causing so many Men and Women in to Financial Hardship if they don't commit suicide first as the system is not based Fairly.

We therefore ask the House to review the Child Support system and base it fairly. If both parents have 50/50 shared care no parent should have to pay as the system overseas. Also if a paying parent is paying it should be based on equal amount of work hours for both parents. If one parent chooses to work Overtime that should not be included in the Child Support calculation. Should be based in an equal amount of hours on both sides.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4267)
Taiwan
The war against Ukraine by Russia has shown us that democracies around the world need to be supported. China and Russia are in alliance, in their joint statement they say:

"Russia and China stand against attempts by external forces to undermine security and stability in their common adjacent regions, intend to counter interference by outside forces in the internal affairs of sovereign countries under any pretext, oppose colour revolutions, and will increase cooperation"

China almost daily threatens to take back Taiwan by force the same way that Russia threatened Ukraine before invading. We should take China at their word and recognize Taiwan and commit to protecting Taiwan against Chinese aggression.
We therefore ask the House to formally recognize the nation of Taiwan and commit to protecting Taiwan against Chinese military aggression.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN4268)
Nuclear Energy
Australia is facing an energy crisis.
Our thermal generation fleet is ageing rapidly and new wind and solar generation isn't providing the same level of price and supply certainty.
The cost of energy, most notably electricity, is rising sharply and the security of supply is declining.
Energy underpins our modern society, it needs to be affordable, but more importantly, it needs to be reliable.
Australia risks economic and social collapse unless the Australian government can guarantee reliable and affordable energy.
Nuclear energy has demonstrated in 32 countries over the past 6 decades that it can provide affordable, reliable and clean energy to sustain modern developed economies.

We therefore ask the House to initiate the International Atomic Energy Agency's milestones approach which helps guide a country through the process of investigating and implementing nuclear energy technology.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4269)
Migration

The plight of tens of thousands of eligible provisional and bridging visa holders in Australia many of whom currently find themselves with limited or no access or support as a result of the extremely blown out processing times for visa's. These are specifically those people who have legally met all of the relevant eligibility criteria for the grant of an Australian SC887 permanent visa and include families with young children. Due to this unexplainable delay we have found ourselves in a seemingly never ending and increasing queue. In the case of an 887 visa applicant the queue has mysteriously increased from weeks to now 24-28 months and is growing longer.

The grant of a permanent residency visa for eligible applicants will help to avoid a potential humanitarian crisis by providing these extremely vulnerable people with the ability to access support for themselves and their families in the challenging times ahead and continue to grow in Australia. Even during the pandemic, we remained in Australia, paid taxes, abided with out visa conditions without any support from the Government. We request urgent action in this matter.

We therefore ask the House to grant all eligible 887 applications immediately, keeping in mind that 887 applicants are not subject to any caps and the grant of the initial provisional visa has already been counted towards previous migration programs and permanent visa places.
Given the unprecedented times we are currently faced with we believe this is an entirely fair, warranted and urgent measure.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4271)
Gambling
The Interactive Gambling Act 2001 needs to be changed to include predatory gambling systems within modern video games.

Video games have been adopting predatory systems of chance/gambling and in-game currencies to influence an ongoing sunk cost fallacy cycle which fosters gambling addiction targeting vulnerable Australian consumer groups.

Video gaming loot boxes, in-game currencies operating secondary markets and micro-transactions are manipulative, exploitative and are overdue for regulation. These systems are influencing younger generations of Australian children to gamble and are coercing today's gaming consumers to pay real money to resolve manufactured inconveniences from game publishers.
This is seen across all major gaming platforms and varies in it's severity.
The Australian Communications and Media Authority enforce regulations based off the Interactive Gambling Act's definition of gambling. This is why the IGA needs to change.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Interactive Gambling Act 2001's definition of "gambling service" to include predatory video game systems such as loot boxes, in-game currencies operating a secondary market which also includes gambling and chance systems. The Australian Communications and Media Authority to the follow up with enforcement after the Interactive Gambling Act definition of "gambling service" has been amended accordingly.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4272)
Gambling

Half a decade ago, the Federal Government introduced the 'Interactive Gambling Amendment Bill (2016)' to the parliament. This was an important piece of legislation that looked to protect problem gamblers. It also wanted to offer protections by banning unlicensed offshore operators and also by clearly clarifying and defining the laws around 'in play' betting.
This was a good initiative and something that was broadly supported by the Australian Poker Community.

Unfortunately, as the Bill is currently written it spelt the end of online poker in Australia, and many well-respected poker websites like WSOP, Pokerstars, GGPoker and 888Poker withdrew services from the country.

Offshore companies run the overwhelming majority of online poker operators utilised by Australians. There are no licensed Australian operators. The difference is that the websites above are not small cowboy operations set up externally to exploit Australian laws. These are large publically listed companies listed on large scale economic centres such as the London Stock Exchange.
The intention of the Bill was not to end online poker in Australia, but as it stands, online poker became a casualty of this bill, destroying a pastime enjoyed by many Australians.
We therefore ask the House to amend the Bill to stipulate the exclusion of online poker.

As consenting citizens of mature age, it is our right to be able to pursue any hobby or pastime we choose as long as it doesn't affect others. One small amendment to this Bill will go a long way to have online poker return to Australia.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN4274)
Cystic Fibrosis

Cystic Fibrosis (CF), the most common life limiting genetic disability, is caused by mutations of the CFTR gene. Some 2500 known mutations are known to this large gene, 90% having one called F508del. Mutations cause defects in a protein that controls the anions Chloride (and less so Bicarbonate) being pumped out of cells. In the lungs, gut and other mucous secreting cells this leads to thick mucous and the symptoms of CF. Recent developments and research has developed a group of drugs known as modulators that improve the excretion of chloride leading to more normal mucous and improved lung function, greatly improving the well-being and lives of the pwCF. Unfortunately, these modulators of which the most recent Trikafta has just been recommended by the PBAC, have only been registered for use in only persons with one or just a very few mutations. Trikafta only for persons with the F508del mutation. This is because large double blinded trials only included that mutation. Vertex's own laboratory research has shown there are 178 mutations that should respond and the US Prescribing Information includes these in their list of mutations for which the drugs can be used. With these rare mutations, such as the one person in Australia with the mutations R75Q and G542X, large double blinded trials are impossible.

We therefore ask the House to make these modulators available for all persons with CF whom reasonable evidence exists that they should benefit, as judged by expert CF Physicians, benefiting about 10 persons.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN4275)
Russia
On 24-Feb-2022, Russia has launched an unprovoked invasion of its peaceful neighbour, Ukraine.

Western countries' response to that unjust war of aggression was multifaceted, from political to economic. Politically, that included Lithuania declaring Russia a terrorist state, with U.S. currently considering a similar designation. Numerous countries deemed the events war crimes and/or genocide. Economically, sanctions have been imposed targeting individuals, banks, and businesses. Australia's response currently comprises import/export restrictions on certain goods (munitions, luxury items, some raw materials), economic activities related to the same, and financial sanctions targeting select individuals and organisations.
