Mr Morrison as Treasure voted 26 times against its establishment. Of intense interest to all previous enquiries was the misconduct of the CBA during the takeover of BankWest in 2009. The Small Business Ombudsman Ms Carnell said of the BankWest issue "This is a significant issue that has loomed large in parliamentary inquiries and has never been satisfactorily resolved' The Commission's Letter Patent asked "whether any conduct by (banks) (including by directors,..) might have amounted to misconduct and, if so, whether the question of criminal..proceedings should be referred to the relevant..agency" Clearly taking the side of banks, the Commissioner made the choice that he would only find misconduct "where the entity concerned acknowledged..that what happened amount to misconduct' The BA was asked if it has engaged in misconduct but predictable CBA did not answer the Commissioners question. It was therefore inevitable that, despite wordy irrelevant discussions of the BankWest issue, the Commissioner ultimately made no finding as to whether CBA/BankWest had or had no engaged in misconduct.

We therefore ask the House to conduct a public inquiry, including giving BankWest victims to give evidence, into the failure of the Banking Royal Commission to make a finding concerning misconduct by CBA/BankWest, the role of Ministers and Government agencies and with particular reference to whether illegal or corrupt practices were involved.
from one citizen (Petition No. PN0543)
Skilled Migration Program
The 3 years living and working requirement of 491 visa to have the permanent residency is really long.

We can't buy houses, we can't study further and we can't purchase any properties. Everything is too expensive for us. We don't have that much freedom. This condition must be reduced please to help us all out in this.
We therefore ask the House to change the 3 year living and working condition on 491 visa. It is really long and we have to wait for 3 more years to get our permanent residencies.
Please help us all out. We are working really hard to fulfil these requirements. Please change the 3 year condition to help us all out.
Thank you
from 272 citizens (Petition No. EN4448)
Film and Video Industry

3 in 5 Australians (58%) are unable to recognise non-consensual acts on screen, and 71% want content providers to classify lack-of-consent in popular movies and shows, in research conducted by PureProfile in 2022.

Non-consensual acts are normalised on screen, in scenes that are funny, romantic and even charming. Leaving them unacknowledged not only fails to inform viewers, it also perpetuates lack-of-consent by miseducating Australians on what consent looks like. Peer-reviewed studies have proven the normalising effects on audiences when sexual coercion is presented in films in a funny or romantic way.

The Australian Classification Board is a government body designed to reflect the community's needs, and in 2015 research commissioned by the Attorney-General, 68% of Australians said they wanted more detail in their classifications, including new classifications to more accurately describe content. A new "lack-of-consent" classification would work in a similar way to existing "coarse language" or "violence" classifications, and appear before viewers watch.
The classification would simply allow viewers to make informed choices about the content they consume, and also educate them to recognise lack-of-consent both on screen, and in real life.
We therefore ask the House to introduce a new classification, (C) Lack of Consent, on all content containing non-consensual sexual acts.
from 1,873 citizens (Petition No. EN4451)
Inland Rail

The Inland Rail line through Wagga Wagga will divide the city into two. The proposed heavy freight trains are to be up to 24 movements day and night, with double stacked containers, trains up to 3.6km long, pulled by multiple diesel locomotives.

To accommodate trains of this size, the Edmondson Street bridge needs to be raised by up to 2.8metres. This bridge is already dangerously steep and has a very short down run to the intersection with the Sturt Highway. Both Bourke & Fernleigh Road rail crossings will cause extended delays and enormous traffic queues each time a train passes through.

With the intended city population to reach 100,000 people by 2040, the impact on how the city functions will be immense. With Sydney reaching its capacity, people are wanting to relocate to regional areas. Whilst Wagga is the state's largest regional city, poor planning decisions will make it less attractive to people who wish to relocate. This is an opportunity to ensure that the city remains a viable and attractive place to live.

Problems if the Inland Rail comes through the centre of Wagga include increased noise all hours of the day/night, vibration, traffic delays, increased risk of accidents, and a physical division of the city.
If the Inland Rail bypasses the Wagga CBD centre, the residents will not be impacted whilst the region will benefit from the financial impacts of the complete project.
We therefore ask the House to change the proposed Inland Rail line to bypass Wagga's CBD centre
from 356 citizens (Petition No. EN4453)
Taxation

The Stage 3 tax cuts were introduced by the former Liberal Party Federal government—when economic conditions were very different to the very poor situation we find ourselves in today. Further, it was voted in with only a margin of 1 vote.

We are now in difficult economic times, our national debt is over a trillion dollars, the Liberal Party lost the election by a great margin and the impact of losing over $240 billion in revenue over the next 10 years when Australia needs it to regenerate itself is a most dangerous action to current Australians and also to future generations. We can and must do better.
We therefore ask the House to immediately stop the Stage 3 tax cuts.

In its place we need to a complete review of the tax system over the next 3 to 5 years to ensure it is fit for purpose—namely, improving the lot of all Australians such that we can all make the most of our lives, while allowing those that are so inclined to improve their wealth and status—but not to the detriment of the majority. We must also consider the long term needs of this great country—so that future generations will be cared for, at least as much as we are.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4454)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Due to the pandemic, children who received NDIS funding as part of the early intervention program were unable to use their funds to access the services required. It is reasonable and fair to apply extensions for these children so they can benefit from the unused funding they were allocated.
We therefore ask the House to change NDIS funding policy on a temporary basis in light of the pandemic. All children should be able to access the intervention services they were promised.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN4457)
Taxation
The severe economic conditions in Australia today and with the wealth gap continuing to widen, we want our tax payer money more wisely spent to benefit all Australians.

We demand that the budget for the proposed Stage 3 income tax cuts—of $243billon—should be scrapped and redirected to provide for all Australians, by reducing the cost of living through investment in:
- education (more money to public schools, fully fund pre-school for 3-5 year olds, make tertiary education free)
- health (e.g. raise GP Medicare Rebate, include dental and mental health to Medicare)
- aged care (e.g. increase aged care workers wages)
- child care (e.g. make it free and increase educators wages)
- mitigating climate change (e.g. invest in rapid decarbonisation of our economy and more sustainable farming practices)
- public & social housing (e.g. build more)
- indigenous issues (e.g. better funding of Closing the Gap initiatives)
- raise pensions (e.g. Jobseeker, Parenting, Carer's, Disability and Aged)
- Fully fund NDIS
- the Arts (e.g. increase funding across Arts industries and for the ABC)

We therefore ask the House to vote to overturn the planned Stage 3 income tax cuts scheduled to come into effect in 2024 before the next federal budget so that alternate investment planning to benefit all Australians can begin as soon as possible.
from 307 citizens (Petition No. EN4458)
Food Labelling

Remove the words meat or chicken or fish from all none meat package and ban vegan fast food chains from say it's meat when it's not. ..( you can't sell a meat rissole sandwich then say it's not meat but a alternative.thats decieve.

We therefore ask the House to investigate and ban all wording meat or associated like chicken or anything say meat banned from all vegan products or packaging if it's not meat it shouldn't be labelled meat or have any words containing meat or chicken on it .if you buy a product that says hamburger..in small letters no meat .that is decieve elderly people are being decieve. Shops put vegan products on shelves next to meat products that's decieve. So all the words meat or chicken should be removed from all packages and shop and fast food restaurants that say buy a chicken burger but their is no chicken .that's a open decieve of people
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4459)
Member for Dickson

In February 2019 Mr Dutton declared he was a beneficiary of RHT family trust in his Register of Members Interests. At the same time the ABN database lists two companies as being the responsibility of RHT family trust, CAMELIA AVENUE CHILDCARE CENTRE and BALD HILLS CHILDCARE CENTRE. The Department of Finance list both of these companies as recipients of Commonwealth funding for many years. After the election Mr Dutton declared he had renounced his family trust and was not a beneficiary. Mr Dutton's wife and children are beneficiaries of the trust and the Commonwealth money given to that trust and the two child care centres. Because his family still benefit that is an indirect pecuniary interest in that trust and a breach of S44 of our constitution. I was denied the chance of taking him to the Court of Disputed Returns because I don't vote in his electorate. The house can't determine if Mr Dutton has or hasn't breached the constitution, that is up to the High Court. S47 is needed to put him to the court for adjudication.

We therefore ask the House to refer Mr Dutton to the High Court to determine if his wife and children getting millions in Commonwealth funding is an indirect pecuniary interest for him and therefore breaches S44 of our constitution. Please consider criminal charges as Mr Dutton knew of his financial status and may have signed a false declaration to nominate.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4465)
Member for Aston

The Canadian High Commission in Canberra and Mr Mendicino the Canadian Minister for Immigration were asked to look at the citizenship of Mr Tudge to determine if Mr Tudge was a Canadian citizen. Both responded saying "Canada's Privacy Act provides Canadian citizens, permanent residents, or individuals present in Canada with the right to access their personal information held by the government and protection of that information against unauthorised use and disclosure." Canadian Privacy law only protects Canadian citizens, residents of Canada and visitors to Canada.
Canadian privacy law does not protect Australians living in Australia unless they are dual citizens like Senator Waters was or Mr Tudge is.

Up until 2009, any child born of a Canadian citizen outside of Canada was automatically a Canadian citizen by descent. Although born in Scotland, this means that Tudge's mother was automatically a Canadian citizen (by descent) at birth and Tudge himself was also a Canadian citizen by descent because his mother was Canadian, whether she knew it or not. Tudge was born in 1971 in Australia and would have almost certainly had triple citizenship at birth—Australian, UK and Canadian. He renounced his UK citizenship before running for office.

The Canadian authorities can not comment on Mr Tudge's Canadian citizenship but if he did not have Canadian citizenship and just Australian citizenship they could say he was not Canadian. They refuse to say that.
We therefore ask the House to use S47 to refer Mr Tudge to the Court for adjudication.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4466)
Education

Humanity's Educational-steps to survive, and live in our Milky-way Galaxy to explore our Universe together: Humanity's greatest commitment is in the process of our conviction to Educate all Children in all cultures about, how they scientifically evolved over Millions of years. That Education Act; will create many thousands of Human-evolution teaching jobs in Australia; then all Children in all cultures will have pleasurable anticipation to be Educated, about their Scientific D.N.A. Genome-setting they inherited from their parents' and their parents' parents.

We therefore ask the House to make this proposed Australian Federal Education legislation into law: Federal Education Bill: Section 1: Introduce one subject ( Human-Evolution ) to be designed by scientific biologists in Australia, presenting a high-quality early Childhood Education to all Students, on their journey through School, into University. Section 2: Introduce one (H-E.E.L. / Human-Evolution Education Law) holding authority over a (compulsory separate curriculum) in grades 1 to 12, for all students in all Australian School cultures to receive 'Scientific Biology lessons about how they Evolved over millions of years; with the Australian Federal Education department, holding management, authority, and financial control, over this legislation.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4467)
Public Holiday: Queen Elizabeth II

Queen Elizabeth II was an extraordinary woman. Whether you are a fan of the monarchy or not it is undeniable that she has been a constant presence in the Australian public consciousness for the last 70 years. That is more than half the time we have been our own nation. She deserves permanent recognition.
We therefore ask the House to establish a federal public holiday each year on the 8th or 9th of September to honour Queen Elizabeth II's memory.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4468)
Temporary Graduate Visas

Temporary Graduate visa (485) holders lived in Australia throughout the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns and supported in the best possible way. The economic support included but not limited to work, study, rental payments, taxes, supporting local businesses and all other Australian retailers. Due to the lockdowns, the probability of getting post study work experience in the desired field reduced drastically leading to loss of time to gain the professional experience. The visa holders who were offshore with no contribution towards Australia during the pandemic were fairly granted an extension (replacement visa) and the onshore 485 visa holders were overlooked which is extremely disappointing for thousands of onshore visa holders. The 485 visa holders who stood by in Australia during the pandemic should also be considered for the replacement visa that can enable them to gain professional experience in their desired field since they have spent a huge amount of money on their stay and study in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to kindly consider the onshore 485 holders who were in Australia throughout the pandemic until December 2021. Similar to consideration of replacement visa for offshore visa holders, a replacement visa or the extension of the 485 visas would be a huge relief for thousands of visa holders.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4469)
Cryptocurrency
Australian Law should be grounded in objective truths and good ethical standards. We see that Bitcoin has become legal tender in El Salvador, and therefore is most definitely a foreign currency.

Bitcoin is a new EMERGING money, with no central leadership to unilaterally make changes to the monetary policy, or dictate its value, or the supply. When fully adopted as money, its value will be stable (against goods and services), and will allow humans to save and PLAN for the future—an important feature of good money. Humans planning with long-term thinking will allow us to build greater things, and humanity will flourish.

Australia should not redefine the truth of what Bitcoin is, and respect its international obligations. The purpose of the redefinition seems to be to squeeze Bitcoin into something it is not, in order to extract tax from Australians. We are doing it tough as it is, and unjust laws to take more from regular people just trying to save in a new emerging money should not be supported.

Providing "clarity" about how more tax will be extracted isn't the desire of the people when it comes to Bitcoin. Clarity about how Bitcoin will be allowed to flourish, not stifled, is what is sought. Laws embracing Bitcoin as a new technological breakthrough as independent money will help Australia's overall wealth—for citizens and the state.
We therefore ask the House to reject changes that redefine Bitcoin in the tax law away from its true status as a foreign currency.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4470)
Australian Currency
The Reserve Bank of Australia writes that the 'Banknotes offer an opportunity to honour Australians who have made important contributions to the nation.'

There is no one more vital to the Australian culture and identity than Steve Irwin. Steve is beloved by all and has become synonymous with the Australian values we hold so dearly. He epitomised the spirit of mateship; he deeply loved the Australian Wildlife, working hard towards conservation and education but perhaps most importantly he's just a good bloke.
This should not be seen as a step away from the crown, but as a step towards honouring a beloved Aussie hero.
There is so much more that could be said about Steve but it comes down to this: we ought to honour a true Aussie hero.
We therefore ask the House to change the face of the $5 note to Steve Irwin
from 2,228 citizens (Petition No. EN4471)
Australian Currency

The death of Queen Elizabeth II and the proclamation of King Charles III raises an important question about the future of Australian currency. Australia achieved full sovereignty from the British on 1 January 1901 and has since developed a rich and diverse culture of its own. We propose keeping all existing $5 notes featuring Queen Elizabeth II in circulation and introducing a new $5 note honouring Australian zookeeper Steve Irwin. Steve Irwin is an Australian cultural icon, conservationist, wildlife expert and environmentalist. This is not intended to disrespect King Charles III, Queen Elizabeth II or the royal family. We are grateful for their continuing service to the Commonwealth of Australia.
We therefore ask the House to keep all notes featuring Queen Elizabeth II in circulation and introduce a new $5 note featuring Steve Irwin.
from 336 citizens (Petition No. EN4472)
Defence Procurement: Submarines

With the Royal Australian Navy looking at acquiring nuclear submarines it should be fitting that they are named after a famous Prime Minister who helped solidify Australia's relationship with the United States.

In December 1967, Holt disappeared while swimming in rough conditions at Cheviot Beach, Victoria. He was presumed dead, although his body was never recovered; his disappearance spawned a number of conspiracy theories. Holt was the third Australian prime minister to die in office. He was succeeded by Country Party leader John McEwen on an interim basis and then by John Gorton. His death was commemorated in a number of ways, among them by the establishment of the Harold Holt Memorial Swimming Centre in Melbourne.
We therefore ask the House to propose that the new class of Nuclear Submarines be named in honour of Harold Holt CH
from 144 citizens (Petition No. EN4473)
Higher Education Contribution Scheme

200,000 students each year are required to undertake extended unpaid full-time placements as part of their degrees to gain up to 1000 hours of supervised practice for anywhere from 4-18 weeks. To prevent burnout, students are advised by universities to reduce or stop working during placements and rely on savings. Unfortunately, given the rising cost of living, many students cannot afford to do this and have no choice but to continue to work alongside their placement.

Understandably, these 60-hour work weeks have impacts on student's health and wellbeing, ability to learn on placement and ultimately, their ability to complete their courses placement requirements. In an ideal world, every student would receive a scholarship, however, these are few and far between for the average student.

One way that this could instead be managed, is the option of a HECS-HELP placement loan; financially covering the decrease in income. Something very similar is currently available to students undertaking elective overseas exchanges (OS-HELP), whereby students can add $7000 to their HECS-HELP debt and receive this in cash. This supports them financially when they want it and they can pay this back later, when they are financially stable.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a placement HECS-HELP loan covering part-time earnings for the number of weeks of the placement. Given a similar scheme is already in place for an elective university option, it does not seem unreasonable for the same to be offered for a compulsory university requirement.
from 9,057 citizens (Petition No. EN4474)
Rural and Regional Health Services

Currently in Far West NSW patients need to travel up to 1200km per week to access dialysis. This places unnecessary risk and burdens onto the patients and their families who not only deal with the challenges of their health but are placed under further duress by way of organising travel (without a vehicle or licence), trying to manage their time away from home (households are reliant on their stable presence to function), costs associated with a 400km plus round trip (fuel and meals) and the normal risks of travel in the outback, such as animal strikes, fatigue and extreme weather. The majority of these patients are Aboriginal, live below the poverty line, deal with chronic illness and disease, and are impacted by the rising costs of living more than those who live in the cities and large towns.

We therefore ask the House to waive any consultation phase and act immediately on the election promise of the Albenese Government to provide $1 million to supply the Far West with two dialysis treatment buses to service Wilcannia, White Cliffs and Menindee. There are examples in remote parts of the country to draw experience from and in the spirit of Closing the Gap we urge you act upon this request.
from 522 citizens (Petition No. EN4477)

subdebateinfo.title: Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia

p.span: Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia

Australia is a constitutional monarchy. Historically and presently we share deep and close ties with the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth realms. We have previously had a sibling or child of the then King serve as Governor-General and plans were in place in the 1970s to appoint the then Prince of Wales, now King Charles III, as Governor-General. To recall and cement our ties to the Australian monarchy, we should have the son or sibling of the monarch of Australia to serve as Governor-General again.

We therefore ask the House to consider requesting the Government of Australia to, at the appropriate time, request His Majesty King Charles III of Australia, appoint His Royal Highness William, Prince of Wales to the position of Governor-General of Australia.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4478)
Parliament
Canada is a country about the same size geographically and the same population as Australia.

Last parliament a petition, EN1024, was put asking parliament sit as often as Canada or the UK. Both of those sit for more than 140 days a year leaving 265 days a year for electorate business and holidays. Mr Porter answered that petition and said parliament sits 133 days a year. Under Commander Morrisons' rule Parliament was empty more than 300 days a year. To the average voter it looked like MPs were doing very little and were in fact scared of appearing in parliament.
We therefore ask the House to We therefore ask the House to match the Canadian and United Kingdom parliaments and sit for 140-160 days a year.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4480)
Australian Constitution
When the referendum on becoming a republic was held in 1999, it failed for two main reasons.

One was that Elizabeth II was well respected and therefore Australians were more willing to accept her continuing as head of state, however Charles III is not as well respected and many people do not want to live under his rule.

The other reason was that the referendum was worded as only allowing one option for the type of republic, which would have resulted in the "president" being a mere puppet for the government. Most Australians wanted a directly-elected president who could wield true power.

We therefore ask the House to hold a new referendum to determine whether Australia should become a republic. We ask that either the question be worded to ensure the president is directly elected, or that the referendum contain two questions. The two questions would be "Should Australia become a republic?" and "What model of republic should we adopt?"
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN4483)
Education Workforce
To hopefully add a new category of education staff that specially accommodates disabled children in school.
We therefore ask the House to consider making it required to have intervention/support staff in every school in Australia.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. PN0544)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following eight ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Arts
Dear Chair
I refer to correspondence of 17 November 2020 regarding Petition EN1674. It is concerning that the previous Liberal and National Government did not respond to this petition from nearly two years ago.
The Arts and Recreation Services industry is important in the economic and social landscape of Australia.

Arts and Recreation Services employs 230,500 people (Australian Bureau of Statistics Labour Force Survey, Detailed, May 2022) in a diverse range of sectors that includes museums, zoos, parks, botanical gardens, creative and performing arts, professional and recreational sports, amusement centres and casinos. More than half of workers have post-school qualifications. This industry includes both professional sportspersons and creative artists who have many years of training in their respective fields, as well as many people in administrative, support and management roles.

As you are aware as Special Envoy for the Arts, my first priority as Minister for the Arts is to work with the Australian creative sector to develop a new cultural policy for the decade ahead. This new policy will be shaped by the diverse voices of the Australian creative sector around the five goals of Creative Australia, launched by then Prime Minister, the Hon Julia Gillard in 20l 3. Further information on the development of the new National Cultural Policy is available at:
www.arts.gov.au/culturalpolicy.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Arts, Mr Burke
Rail Network
Dear Ms Templeman

On 22 November 2021 the former Chair of Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd, wrote to the former Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, the Hon Barnaby Joyce MP, regarding Petition Number EN3432—a proposal to purchase TGV trains from France. Mr O'Dowd's letter was not responded to prior to the last election and has now been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I note that the petitioners are concerned about climate change and contend that the purchase of TGV trains and construction of a high-speed rail (HSR) network along Australia's east coast would help mitigate its impact. The petitioners have also linked their proposal with the former Government's decision to cancel its submarine contract with France, arguing that such a purchase would help to repair Australia's bilateral relationship with France.

The delivery of an east coast HSR system between Brisbane and Melbourne is a key election commitment of the Government and will initially be supported by a $500 million investment to begin planning and secure a corridor between Sydney and Newcastle. To coordinate and drive the delivery of the HSR project, the Government has also committed to creating a High Speed Rail Authority. The Authority will work closely with all levels of government, industry and other stakeholders to plan and implement the project.

It is too early at this stage to be able to specify what trains a east coast HSR system will need. The project has to be planned and developed first, and this will include specifying the type of trains required. At a future stage of the project, procurement for the trains would occur and I would expect this would follow competitive tendering processes to ensure value for money.
I trust this information addresses the request made in the petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Brumbies
Dear Chair

Thank you for correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for the Environment, the Hon Sussan Ley MP, concerning EN3929 on wild living brumbies facing archaic cruel and inhumane aerial and ground shooting, causing protracted cruel deaths. Your correspondence has been referred to me as it falls under my responsibilities as the Minister for the Environment and Water.

Protecting Australia's unique environment, including its biodiversity, is important to the Australian Government and to the people of Australia. 'Novel biota and their impact on biodiversity' is a listed key threatening process under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999(Cth) (EPBC Act). The listing specifically refers to the impact that invasive vertebrate pests, such as horses, have on native species. I note that the debate relating to feral horses has particularly focussed on their presence in the Australian Alps, which is a National Heritage listed place under the EPBC Act for its unique natural environment and outstanding landscape value.

The on-ground management of established non-native animals is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments and land managers. Each state and territory is responsible for the regulation of feral horses including on matters such as animal welfare. My expectation is that states and territories will take responsible and humane measures to sustainably manage the presence of feral horses in the landscape, including to protect the natural values of Australia's National Heritage listed places.
I thank the Committee for bringing this matter to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 27 September 2022 concerning petition EN4062 to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt, regarding the recommendation from the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) to not support public funding of Vertebral Body Tethering (VBT) for the treatment of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS).

The MSAC is an independent committee that appraises new medical services and provides advice to the Australian Government on whether they should be publicly funded based on an assessment of comparative safety, clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness, using the best available evidence. In order for a new medical service to be funded through the MBS, an assessment by MSAC is required. The MSAC health technology assessment process is comprehensive, comprising presentation of the evidence of comparative safety, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness by the applicant in the form of an assessment report, an independent critique of the assessment report, provision of advice to MSAC from the MSAC Evaluation Subcommittee and input from clinicians, consumers and relevant organisations through public and targeted consultation processes.

In assessing the application for VBT for the treatment of AIS, MSAC considered that the evidence for comparative safety, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness for VBT compared with posterior spinal fusion (PSF) was uncertain and more data was needed. Therefore, MSAC did not recommend separate MBS items numbers for VBT.

It is important to note that VBT has never been listed on the MBS. MSAC considered the use of MBS item numbers 51021-51026 and 51165 for VBT is not in alignment with the procedures described by the items. To ensure clarity, MSAC recommended that the existing items available for other treatments such as PSF should be amended to make it explicit they cannot be claimed for VBT.

MSAC noted that there is an upcoming randomised controlled trial in a population similar to the proposed MBS population, and that it may provide more data in the future. MSAC advised that the applicant could resubmit the application when these data become available; however, larger studies and longer-term follow-up is also needed.

To enable an MSAC reconsideration of VBT, a further submission addressing the matters raised by MSAC for application 1656 would be required. Anyone is able to submit an application to MSAC, however due to the level of evidence that would be required, a medical professional group, such as the Spinal Society of Australia, is generally best placed to provide the necessary research and trial data. More information about MSAC is available at www.msac.gov.au.

It is important to the integrity of the Medicare system that providers only claim Medicare items that are intended for use with particular treatments. Under the Health Insurance Act 1973, for Medicare benefits to apply, an MBS service must be clinically relevant, and all elements of an item descriptor must be satisfied.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Fuel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4085 on petrol prices and fuel excise.

In the 2022-23 Budget the previous Government halved the fuel excise rate for a period of six months from 30 March 2022 to 11:59 pm on 28 September 2022. This change has ended as legislated and the excise rates have reverted to previous rates, including indexation that would have occurred on those rates during the six-month period.

The Government recognises that the cost of fuel is putting family and business budgets under significant pressure. However, given the state of the Commonwealth budget, the Government is not in a position to extend this measure beyond the already legislated end date.

It is critical that fuel companies promptly pass on reductions in international oil prices and do not take advantage of the end of the excise reduction to penalise consumers. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is responsible for monitoring fuel prices and plays a critical role in ensuring that market participants do not take advantage of consumers. The Treasurer has written to the Chair of the ACCC, Ms Gina Cass-Gottlieb, instructing the Commission to step up its surveillance of fuel markets ahead of, and following, the reintroduction of the full excise rate. As the independent regulator enforcing Australia's competition and consumer laws, the ACCC will investigate concerns about anti-competitive conduct and misleading representations in fuel markets and take appropriate action. The ACCC is also engaging with major retailers and wholesalers to ensure that they do not mislead Australian consumers about the rationale for any price rises.

The level of competition between fuel retailers is also very important. To help drive competition, the ACCC recommends that consumers take advantage of fuel price websites and mobile applications that allow them to select the best time.to purchase fuel, as well as the cheapest location.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Illicit Drugs: Cannabis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022, on behalf of the Petitions Committee reference number EN4102, regarding the legalisation of cannabis.

The Australian Government does not plan to legalise the use of cannabis for non-medical purposes at the national level. Issues relating to the legalisation or decriminalisation of cannabis are the responsibility of states and territories, therefore, the petitioner may like to raise this matter with their relevant state or territory government.

The Government's concerns with the non-medical use of cannabis, which is not under a doctor's supervision, are primarily based on the potential physiological and mental health impacts of cannabis. Tetrahydrocannabinol, which is often at high levels in illicit cannabis products, can lead to exacerbation of mental health conditions as well as decreased motor function, chronic bronchitis, and increased risk of stroke.

The National Drug Strategy 2017-2026, which is the overarching framework identifying national priorities relating to alcohol, tobacco and other drugs, identifies cannabis as a priority substance for action and outlines a range of evidence-based approaches to minimise the harms associated with cannabis use. These harms can be dependent on the age of the person, pattern of use, other risky behaviours and the interaction with individual health concerns. While many Australians may view cannabis as harmless, 20% of Australia's drug and alcohol treatment episodes are being provided to people identifying cannabis as their principal drug of concern.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Chair

I am writing in response to your correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Acting Minister for Education and Youth regarding Petition EN3892 to include specific sexual education content relating to LGBTQIA+ communities.
In response to the issues raised in the petition, I can provide the following advice.
The current Australian Curriculum

The Foundation to Year 10 (F-10) Australian Curriculum (the curriculum) was developed by the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA), and provides a national approach to the content students are taught in schools.

Under the F—10 Australian Curriculum: Health and Physical Education (HPE), students are given the opportunity to engage with age-appropriate sex education that is designed to be inclusive and meet the learning needs of all students. In addition to the content outlined in HPE, students also have the opportunity to learn about beliefs and values that will help them to engage appropriately with their learning and navigate life outside of school. The general capabilities of Personal and Social Capability and Ethical Understanding encourage students to engage respectfully with LGBTQIA+ issues.
The Australian Curriculum Review

In 2015, education ministers agreed reviews of the curriculum would occur every 6 years. The last review was in 2014. In June 2020, the Education Council agreed to the terms of reference for the current review to refine, realign and declutter the content of the curriculum and to ensure the curriculum remains current and continues to meet the needs of students.

In undertaking the review ACARA, the organisation responsible for the administration of the curriculum, ran a public consultation between April and July 2021 on a new draft of the curriculum. It was the first time the curriculum had been made available for public consultation and the public interest demonstrated the importance of what our students learn.
As a part of this process ACARA engaged with educational experts to consider how the HPE curriculum could better support the teaching of respectful relationships.

Education ministers met on 1 April 2022 and endorsed the updated curriculum, which will be ready for implementation in schools from 2023. All ministers have also requested ACARA undertake further work on the mental health aspects of the HPE curriculum.

span.span: The roles of states and territories and the Australian Government

p.span: While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, state and territory governments and non-government education authorities and individual schools are responsible for the day-to-day delivery of education programs and the curriculum, taking into account their context and community needs.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Dental Health
Dear Chair,

Thank you for your email of 31 March 2022, to the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon Andrew Gee MP, regarding the petition submitted to the House of Representatives about the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) Osseo-integrated Dental Implant Policy and Guidelines.

DVA began funding the replacement of single missing teeth with dental implants in 2006 following a submission to the Repatriation Commission and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission (the Commissions). The submission noted the intent of this policy would be to replace teeth, which were recently lost, defined as within the preceding three years, known as the 'three year rule'. The submission described concerns raised regarding the potential for implant failure where bone quality had degraded over periods greater than three years.

In 2013, DVA commenced a review of these arrangements which sought to determine whether the policy continued to be supported by clinical evidence. As part of the review, DVA sought advice from the Australian Dental Association (ADA), on whether the 'three year rule' is still clinically supported. The ADA advised that it no longer supports the rule, noting implant procedures have advanced since their introduction.

DVA acknowledges this viewpoint, however, there are a number of alternative clinically effective options to address tooth loss including partial dentures and dental bridges, which do not carry the risks associated with dental implants including bone loss; infection; nerve damage; damage to the sinus; and damage to surrounding teeth or blood vessels.

Under DVA's health care arrangements, DVA will fund all clinically necessary treatment for eligible clients. DVA considers clinically necessary treatment to be a service which restores the primary function of the affected body part. In many circumstances, there are alternatives available to dental implant treatment, which are commonly used in Australia due to their reduced cost and limited invasiveness.

When considering requests for treatment through the prior financial authorisation process, delegates are required to adhere to the Treatment Principles and Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA) Treatment Principles, which require them to take into account:
any specific requirements contained in the Principles;
the extent of funds that are available;
reasonable control over expenditure;
the clinical need for the proposed treatment; and
the suitability and quality of the proposed treatment.

Where a request for treatment is outside the policies endorsed by the Commissions, consideration must be given to lower cost alternatives which present a lower clinical risk to mitigate the risk of potential harm to the client and additional funding required to resolve complications. Where clients have been missing teeth for greater than three years, without replacement, this may indicate that replacement of that tooth was not clinically necessary.

There are a number of lower risk services available to DVA clients who are missing teeth including dentures and dental bridges. These services do not require any form of surgery and may also represent better value for money than a dental implant. The National Study of Adult Oral Health 2017-18 conducted by the University of Adelaide's Australian Research Centre for Population Oral Health identified that approximately 47 per cent of individuals over 75 years of age wore dentures with only 10 per cent reporting to have dental implants.

For the Australian public, the availability of dental treatment within the current market is regulated by their ability to afford certain services. As DVA fully funds the majority of dental services for eligible clients, such matters are often not considered by DVA clients when presented with dental implant services options.

DVA understands the impact missing teeth may have on an individual, and operates its Dental Program to ensure all clients are provided equitable access to services. Any changes to the DVA Dental Program to increase the availability of high cost dental implant treatment would require consideration by Government through the Budget process. Notwithstanding this, given the ongoing concerns raised, particularly in relation to the 'three year rule', DVA has included consideration of this issue, and the broader implant policy, into the review of the DVA Dental Program currently underway and due to be completed by December 2022.
Thank you again for providing me the opportunity to respond to the petition. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Keogh
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): This bumper crop of petitions is the petitions that were requested during the election period and approved by the committee in its first meetings. After four weeks gathering signatures, these petitions are now presented to the House.

These 173 petitions represent over 80,000 signatures from Australians seeking improvement or change. Twelve petitions had over 1,000 signatures each, with topics ranging across health, immigration, foreign affairs and taxation. Over 2,500 Australians would like Steve Irwin to be on the $5 note.

After presentation to the House, each of these petitions will be referred to the relevant minister for a response. These responses are due within 90 days. Ministers are required to provide responses, even when the matter relates to decisions or actions of a previous minister or a previous government.

The committee appreciates the efforts of ministers and their staff to respond to petitions in a timely way; however, there are a number of petitions that have not yet received a response. Over the next few weeks the committee will send reminders to ministers with information about any outstanding petitions.
Ministerial responses are an essential link in the chain of the petitioning process and I look forward to presenting more in the future.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Cybersecurity
Mrs ANDREWS (McPherson) (10:03): I move:
That this House:
(1) notes that the:
(a) Optus and Medibank data breaches highlight the threats faced by Australians and Australian businesses from cyber-criminals;
(b) previous Government passed significant legislation to help protect Australians and our critical infrastructure from cyber-criminals; and
(c) Government's lacklustre response to the data breaches does nothing to allay the concerns and fears of Australians who may have been impacted by these cyber-attacks; and

(2) calls on the Government to support the passage of the Crimes Legislation Amendment (Ransomware Action Plan) Bill 2022, which would help law enforcement disrupt and deter cyber-criminals who engage in ransomware and cyber-extortion activities targeting Australians and Australian businesses.

I move this motion on behalf of all Australians who have been impacted by, and who remain unsure and worried about, the extent of very serious cyberbreaches that have occurred in recent months—particularly, and notably, at both Optus and Medibank.

The silence from the government has been deafening on these breaches. The recent sobering annual threat assessment from the Australian Cyber Security Centre has documented our deteriorating cyber environment and has recognised cyberspace as a leading domain for warfare and crime, including extortion, espionage and fraud. The ACSC's third Annual cyber threat report revealed that it received over 76,000 cybercrime reports last financial year—a 13 per cent increase from the year before. That means the agency is receiving a report every seven minutes compared to one every eight minutes the year before.

In government, the coalition recognised the threat and took decisive action to harden our defences. We invested a record $1.6 billion to strengthen Australia's cybersecurity defences and meet emerging challenges in order to keep Australians safe. We boosted online safety with $125 million and a range of measures to keep Australians safe online, including the Online Safety Act 2021. We created new capability to identify and block SMS scams at their source. We gave police the powers they needed to police the dark web by passing groundbreaking new laws that allow law enforcement to intercept and disrupt organised criminals, paedophiles and drug pushers on the dark web and to shut down their evil trade. We introduced world-leading legislation to harden the defences of our critical infrastructure and systems of national significance, to ensure the community was better protected against serious cybersecurity incidents. We introduced the ransomware bill, referenced in this motion, which we re-introduced into this parliament and which we call on the government to support. It would create tougher penalties for cybercriminals.

And, importantly, we funded project REDSPICE in the March budget to meet the ongoing challenges we face as a nation. It's critical that project REDSPICE is delivered in full. REDSPICE is the single most significant investment to transform the Australian Signals Directorate's offensive and defensive capabilities. That's why last week I joined with my colleagues the shadow minister for defence and the shadow minister for cyber security to call on the Albanese government to guarantee future funding for offensive and defensive cybercapabilities.

The Albanese government should also support the swift passage of the coalition's ransomware bill, which increases penalties for a range of cybercrimes to give law enforcement, working in conjunction with our intelligence agencies, another tool to pursue cybercriminals. Our bill, which we first introduced earlier this year, would introduce a new standalone offence for all forms of cyberextortion so that cybercriminals who use ransomware face an increased maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment. It also introduced a new aggravated offence for cybercriminals seeking to target critical infrastructure, recognising the significant impact on assets that deliver essential services, with a maximum penalty of 25 years imprisonment. And it ensures that law enforcement can monitor and free the ill-gotten gains of cybercriminals by extending current powers that cover financial institutions to digital currency exchanges.

We don't pretend that this bill is a silver bullet, because no such thing exists, but it will present a new deterrent to these cybercriminals, and it is an important part of safeguarding Australians. Labor's absence on ransomware legislation is truly baffling, particularly when an alternative bill has been presented into this House. We on this side of the chamber remain very committed to ensuring that everything that can possibly be done is done to protect Australians. We are also concerned to make sure that Australians are given the information that they need, firstly to be able to protect themselves, but, when they have been the subject of a significant data breach or ransomware attack or any cybersecurity incident, they are getting the information they need to protect, as much as possible, their data.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Dr Freelander ): Is the motion seconded?
Mr Wallace: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Ms MILLER-FROST (Boothby) (10:08): I thank the member for raising this important and timely issue of cybersecurity. It is clear that the recent spate of cybersecurity breaches has had a significant impact on a large number of Australians. Whether they were directly affected or not, the breaches have had an impact on their sense of personal security and on their ability to have confidence in the digital systems that we increasingly use to run and coordinate our lives. Many Australians have had some of their most sensitive financial or health data accessed by criminals, and, anecdotally, particularly since the Optus and Medibank data hacks, people in Boothby have been at pains to impress upon me the increase in spam messages, phone calls and unwanted electronic communications that they have received. At a time when, increasingly, we conduct our lives with government departments, agencies and service providers—and even with retail—online and via text message, these scams directly mimic those interactions and undermine our confidence in the systems.

I'm proud to stand here as a member of the government that is working tirelessly to respond to this enormous challenge. Our data is, potentially, held by many, many companies and agencies, including in the private, not-for-profit and government sectors. We now know that a data security breach is reported in Australia every seven minutes. While not all are as significant as the Optus or Medibank hacks, which impacted potentially millions of Australians, each breach is a serious invasion of privacy. It was reported this morning that 9.7 million current and former Medibank customers have had their personal data included in this latest hack. Even if there is no financial loss, these data breaches cause major disruption and can be extremely unsettling. The inconvenience of having to have all of your ID and financial cards reissued has been a challenge for many of our citizens.

The area of cybersecurity is also a constantly evolving and mutating area of criminal activity, and that is why this government is putting so much focus and expertise into tracking down those criminals who seek to do harm to law-abiding Australian citizens. The Albanese Labor government is managing the consequences of cyber breaches by coordinating government responses and bringing together efforts of multiple government and law enforcement agencies. Just as critically, we are ensuring Australians have the information and tools they need to be protected from harm. The member's characterisation of the government's response to recent high-profile data breaches is disingenuous at best. The Minister for Home Affairs, Clare O'Neil, has led the coordination of multiple federal, state and territory agencies and departments to support a rapid, focused response. To respond to the Medibank incident, the Albanese government activated the National Coordination Mechanism to ensure that all possible support is being provided both to Medibank and to those Australians affected.

The National Coordination Mechanism brings together agencies of the Australian government, state and territory, as well as industry and private sector stakeholders. The Australian Cyber Security Centre has been providing technical advice and assistance. The Australian Federal Police are leading the criminal investigation. The Department of Home Affairs has been supporting Services Australia and the department of health to work with Medibank to confirm what information has been exposed and to put protections in place. Services Australia have put in place proactive mitigation measures focusing on minimising exposure of customer records and protecting the agency's claims infrastructure.

The recent cyber incidents have highlighted the previous government's failings to create effective incident coordination and response mechanisms or fit-for-purpose legal powers to manage the consequences. This is, sadly, no surprise, given that the former government abolished the dedicated role for cybersecurity in the ministry, just when Australia most needed to be getting ahead of these cybercriminals.

Cybersecurity is a serious challenge for any government, and this government is determined to keep Australians safe online. It's a serious area of public policy, so it's unsurprising that those opposite can muster little more than a feeble critique. They've never really been in the business of solving problems for the Australian people. It is, however, good that those opposite now realise how urgent this is, as their previous actions were—as with so many things—too little too late.

Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (10:13): I rise to speak on this motion and to express my concern that the bill I seconded just a few weeks ago has been stonewalled by this Labor government. While Labor dithers and delays on cybersecurity, those who would do us harm continue to maliciously attack our small and family businesses and our critical infrastructure. This is the trend that, unfortunately, we are seeing more and more of. According to the ACSC's report released just last week, we've seen 76,000 cyberattacks over the last financial year. That equates to an attack every seven minutes. But those are just the reported attacks. How many unreported attacks are going on in this country? As the ACSC has noted, cyberspace is becoming a battleground, and we're seeing that most notably, of course, in Ukraine. It's not just cybercriminals, however, who are seeking to do Australians harm. Many attacks are being perpetrated by organisations within foreign governments designed to disrupt our very way of life and cause civil disharmony.

The bill that I seconded just a few short weeks ago, introduced by the member for McPherson, the shadow home affairs minister, was based on legislation we introduced when we were in government earlier this year. It would specifically reform criminal law and secure tougher penalties for all forms of cyberextortion in the event of the exact cybersecurity issues that we've been seeing in recent months—particularly in recent months in Australia. It forms part of the Ransomware Action Plan that the previous coalition government launched last year under the guidance of the then Minister for Home Affairs. It's a practical solution to an issue which costs as much as US$20 billion each year, and the number of those affected is only growing: Optus, Medibank, MyDeal, UnitingCare Queensland and Toll Holdings Ltd. These are enormous companies in Australia which hold very, very sensitive data on probably just about every Australian. Australians expect that their data will be protected. Australians expect that their government would take action to disrupt, deter and punish those involved in malicious cybercrimes such as these ransomware attacks. The opposition has offered good legislation to this government, free to take, free to implement and free to protect Australians' information. Instead, they seek to play politics by blocking sensible bills put forward by this opposition. And it is Australians and their businesses who are left to wear the consequences of serious data breaches.

So what is Labor going to do about this? It is essential that Labor outline what they are going to do about cybersecurity and data protection in our country. This is not a question of just hosting another summit or another talkfest; what are they going to do to get down to work and fix this problem? That is what Australians expect their governments to do; they expect them to work. Will Australians see the ransomware bill across the finish line in a show of bipartisanship on security? Will they consider the other measures which we brought to the table to protect Australians and their interests? Will they retain and deliver in full the record funding of almost $10 billion that we, when we were in government, made to implement Project REDSPICE, to strengthen our offensive and defensive cybercapabilities through the Australian Signals Directorate? It is absolutely imperative that we as a nation strengthen our ability to attack these sources that are seeking to attack us. It's not just a question of defensive measures; we have to increase and enable much better offensive mechanisms.

Lastly, I want to comment that there's no point in just putting investment into ambulances. We have to try and prevent things as well, which is what we're trying to do. I want to give a big shoutout to IDCARE, an organisation in my electorate which was funded by us when we were in government. If you have had your identity stolen or put at risk, contact IDCARE—do a Google search for IDCARE—and they will help you.

Mr GEORGANAS (Adelaide) (10:18): In the last few weeks Australians have been rocked by two of the biggest data breaches and cybercrimes our country has seen—that is, Optus and Medibank. They happened so quickly and in such close succession that it has left people feeling even more vulnerable than before. Firstly, to the millions of Australians who have been affected by these data breaches: I express my sympathies and can understand the angst that you're feeling. It has been a difficult and worrying time for everyone. But I would also like to assure you that this government is doing everything to ensure that your personal information is better protected. This is more important than ever before. Just last week, the Australian Cyber Security Centre's Annual threat report, as we heard from the member for Fisher, found that a cybercrime is being reported every seven minutes in Australia. The report also showed an increase of 13 per cent in cybercrime in the previous year—and that was even before the Optus and Medibank issues occurred.

This is a very serious problem, one that exists in part because of inaction of the previous government over the past decade. Our existing privacy laws were left hopelessly outdated by the former government and they are not strong enough to ensure that our companies adequately protect the private information of Australians. If this can happen to Optus and to Medibank, two of the biggest company organisations in Australia, imagine what could happen to our smaller firms, our NGOs and smaller companies that maybe don't have the same resources that these two big companies have.

In comparison to the former government, this Albanese Labor government has reacted quickly, resolutely and with force to the recent attacks. We have wasted absolutely no time in introducing legislation that will significantly increase penalties for these serious or repeated data breaches. Currently, the maximum fine is $2.2 million. Let's face it: that is a pittance for some of these big companies. It really is not a deterrent; $2.2 million is peanuts. We need penalties that ensure that corporations storing Australians' data feel the full weight of responsibility and obligation to look after it properly. It is their responsibility to look after it properly, and Australians deserve nothing less. Therefore, the penalties we're proposing will be up to $50 million or three times the turnover for the relevant period. That could mean, for a large corporation, fines in the orders of hundreds of millions of dollars. We need a deterrent. Such fines are much harder to ignore and will act as a significant incentive for companies to take their data-protection obligations extremely seriously.

This bill I'm talking about will also give the Information Commissioner additional powers to make companies comply with their obligations to protect our data. As I said, when they store our data, our personal information, they have an absolute responsibility to ensure that it's stored properly. The bill will equip the Australian Information Commissioner and the Australian Communications and Media Authority to have greater information-sharing powers. But our efforts won't stop there, because this is a serious problem. In addition to the legislation, the Albanese Labor government is undertaking a comprehensive review of the Privacy Act. This review is expected to be completed this year and will contain a raft of recommendations for further reform.

Australians can have faith in this government's commitment to ensuring that their data and personal information are protected. That is the starting point: their information must be protected. While there is no doubt that the world has changed, there is also no doubt that governments and businesses must adapt to this new threat. And it is a threat: one attack every seven minutes is a serious threat. It's not just Optus and Medibank; many organisations have been attacked by cyberthreats et cetera. This is precisely why this government is putting legislation in place to protect Australians' private details. It's also precisely what the previous government failed to do. Unlike them, we understand that when Australians hand over their personal information they have a right to expect it will be protected.

Mr HASTIE (Canning) (10:23): I've often said that the cyber domain is the new international battleground. We've always thought about war in terms of air, sea and land, but if you own a smartphone and you're connected then you're on the battlefield, whether you realise it or not. This reality struck hard in September when Optus was the subject of a major cyberattack, affecting around 10 million Australians. Contact details and passport, drivers licence and Medicare numbers were compromised and hung over the head of Australians by cybercriminals. According to the Minister for Cyber Security, 2.8 million Australians had a significant amount of data taken—a serious breach—yet the minister saw it as more appropriate to tweet about the AFL grand final before publicly addressing the Optus attack.

Last month Medibank fell victim to a cyberattack where 3.9 million customers were affected. After a slow and confused response to the Optus incident, it took the minister a week to publicly respond to the Medibank hack, delaying government engagement. In a speech to parliament, the minister referred to the Medibank hack as 'an urgent wake-up call for Australia'. Yes, but it should not have been an urgent wake-up call for the government. When Australians hand over their personal data, they have a right to expect it will be protected. The annual cyberthreat report released by the Australian Cyber Security Centre last week concedes that cyberincidents are growing in severity. In 2021-22 over 76,000 cybercrime reports were made, an increase of nearly 13 per cent from the previous year. That means one cybercrime report is being made approximately every seven minutes. The ACSC also reported an average of 69 calls to the Cyber Security Hotline every day, an increase of 15 per cent.

These are alarming figures, yet while cybercrime is on the rise our government is asleep at the wheel. Since the Optus attack, there has been no legislative response from the Albanese government. Instead, all we have seen the government do is host a virtual International Counter Ransomware Task Force. Labor must ensure that there are stronger penalties in place for cybercriminals seeking to use ransomware. A private members' bill recently introduced by the opposition, based on legislation introduced by the former coalition government, would specifically reform criminal law and secure tougher penalties for all forms of cyberextortion in the event of the exact cybersecurity issues we've been seeing. Disappointingly, in the week after we introduced the bill, Labor members on the Selection of Bills Committee blocked it from progressing for further evaluation, despite failing to provide any of their own legislation to deter cybercriminals.

While Labor stalls on legislation that the opposition is handing to them on a platter, Australians are continuing to fall victim to data breaches. I ask the government: what are they waiting for? The proof that the cyber domain is getting more dangerous is right in front of them in the ACSC's report, signed off by the Deputy Prime Minister. When will Australians stop having to pay the price for this government's inaction? In comparison, the former coalition government passed significant legislation to help protect Australians and our critical infrastructure. In November 2021, based on recommendations from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, we passed important amendments to Australia's national security legislation to better safeguard our community and economy from cybersecurity threats. Earlier this year, we launched the National Plan to Combat Cybercrime and opened a new cybercrime centre led by the Australian Federal Police. In March, the coalition government launched the most significant single investment in the Australian Signals Directorate's 75 years—REDSPICE, a $9.9 billion project to respond to the deteriorating strategic circumstances in our region. Last week I joined my colleagues the shadow minister for cyber security and the shadow minister for home affairs in calling on the government to guarantee that project REDSPICE, funded in the March budget, will be delivered in full.

We need to see Labor commit to investing in offensive and defensive cybercapabilities; to work with industry to protect Australia from the escalating cyberthreat; and to expedite the passage of new ransomware bills. The Australian people simply cannot afford any more delays, confusion or uncertainty from the Albanese government. This government's absence on ransomware legislation is harming Australians by the day, particularly when this bill has now been presented and Labor's only response to this issue is a task force. That's why I'm calling on Labor to support the swift passage of the coalition's bill, which increases penalties for a range of cybercrimes in order to give law enforcement, working in conjunction with our intelligence agencies, another tool to pursue cybercriminals. This bill is not a silver bullet, but it is a step in the right direction towards further safeguarding our digital future. It must be supported by a broad range of legislative, policy and operational reforms. The coalition stands ready to support measures to bolster Australia's defences to the ongoing cyberthreat, and the passage of this bill would be a helpful start.

Mr KHALIL (Wills) (10:28): Australians have every right to be concerned about the Optus and Medibank data breaches, which have exposed the sensitive information of thousands of people and businesses. Of course, they rightly expect the Australian government to do everything it can to respond to such cyberattacks. But I have to say that this motion is simply absurd. For those on the other side to come in here and make such a brazen, politicised attempt to pull the wool over the Australian people's eyes is just astounding. Previous speakers have claimed that the Morrison government passed significant legislation to protect Australians from cybercriminals. Really? Then how do they explain these breaches? Why did their significant legislation fail to protect Australians and critical infrastructure?

I know why it failed and the former Minister for Home Affairs—the same person who moved this motion—knows why it failed. When the breaches occurred, she, along with opposition leader, Peter Dutton, led a conga line of shadow ministers and all the political-puppet-show opposition speakers on this motion in seeking to ascribe blame to the new government and the minister while avoiding any responsibility. It was the member for McPherson, when she was home affairs minister, who switched on the cyberincident and critical infrastructure register reporting obligations for the critical infrastructure sectors on 8 April 2022. So far so good, but here's the kicker: it was her and the Morrison government that decided to leave out the telco sector. They left out telecommunications. That meant, not only did they leave the door unlocked in this very dangerous cybersecurity neighbourhood when there is a rise of cyberattacks and cybercriminals, they left the door wide open, they left the backdoor open, they left the windows open.

The former government told the intelligence and security committee they would turn them on if their existing obligations under the telco act were assessed as being unsuitable. But rather than proactively assessing the suitability of obligations on telcos, in classic form of this opposition when they were in government, they kicked it into the long grass. So, when the Optus breach happened, response powers could not deployed to support Optus to respond to the incident. It was not just the former Minister for Home Affairs who was responsible, despite her brazen attempt through this motion to absolve herself of responsibility, the former minister for communications Paul Fletcher did not switch on the obligations for the telecommunications sector under the SOCI Act either. He should've been well informed—

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Dr Freelander ): Order! Mr Hastie, on a point of order.
Mr Hastie: I'd ask the member to refer to members by their correct titles, please. That's twice he's done it.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Dr Freelander ): The member is correct. I remind the member for Wills.

Mr KHALIL: I'll do so going forward. He should've been well informed; he was an Optus executive. It's an absolute disgrace that they would come in here today and pretend that this failure is anything but one of their own making.

It was the Albanese Labor government that actually applied the cyberincident and critical infrastructure register reporting to the telecommunications sector after the election—straight after the election! We addressed the gap in the application of the SOCI obligations for telcos. Not only that, after the former coalition government abolished the role entirely, we established a cabinet level Minister for Cyber Security. She's been working hard, working with the agencies to actually address these problems to enhance coordination across government on cyberpolicy, cyberstrategy and cyber-response mechanisms. Thank goodness we did, because from the outset Minister O'Neil has been leading a dedicated team who have been working around the clock to protect Australians. We've had the toughest and smartest people in Australia and in the government working tirelessly to respond. That includes the excellent team at the Australian Signals Directorate, who are continuously updating the minister on active cyberincidents. They deserve our thanks, not the former government who made their job even harder.

Significant support is also being provided by the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Home Affairs to the Medibank and Optus incidents. And, of course, the AFP is leading a criminal investigation to hunt down and prosecute the attackers. Home Affairs has led the coordination of multiple federal, state and territory agencies and departments to support the response and put protections in place. To all of those dedicated public servants, I say thank you. Beyond the politicisation of this motion, they are doing a great job and they should be thanked. Unlike those on the other side of the House, they're not trying to escape blame or point the finger at others. They're taking responsibility and doing what needs to be done. I want them all to know that the Albanese government is right on their side, and all Australians, in protecting them from these attacks.

We're cracking down on hackers. We're making it clear with major increased penalties that companies have an obligation to protect consumer data. It's the Albanese Labor government that is actually putting all of these things in place to protect Australians.

Mr BROADBENT (Monash) (10:33): There's a lot of blame being thrown around this morning during this debate, which surprises me, but it probably shouldn't surprise me with the length of time that I have served here. In the book, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, which I recommend everybody read—written so many years ago—it describes exactly what we're going through at the moment. Our heroine uses her considerable skills in the cyberspace to bring down her enemy either in information or in financial movements across the country, across the world. We are now living in that space. It's been coming for 20 years. I don't think Optus or Medibank enjoyed being hacked.

There's a sort of personal arrangement in this for me too. There's a building company—not a large company but not a small company—building homes, residences, trading really well, with a fantastic product. I asked a friend of the owner: 'What happened to the business? How did it go broke, when it was such a good business?' He said, 'To tell you the truth, it started with a ransomware attack on the company that cost the company $1 million to fix.' Now, if it had only involved that, the company could have survived easily, except that there were other forces that then came in. They included COVID and the mandates that were put in by the Victorian government that didn't allow their workforce to move. Their workforce was one that moved from site to site, wherever they were building homes. Because they were unable to move, they then—but that's a whole other story. Anyway, there were other problems with it. But it began with a ransomware attack on the company, which cost them $1 million to fix.

That means it's not just about the Medibanks and the big organisations. We're under threat as individuals. That was a family owned company and they have lost everything. They've lost their homes and they've lost their offices. They've lost everything. I hope and pray they will start again. But this is what happens, living in cyberspace as we do today. A member of the family was about to make a payment on the building of a residence. For some reason, he felt uncomfortable. It was for $35,000 and he was just about to, bang, press the button. He rang the builder and he said, 'Mate, it's got your name,' and everything was there, exactly the same as the last one that he paid. But, actually, he had been hacked and, had he pressed the button, $35,000 would have gone straight into an account somewhere in Australia and then straight overseas within minutes. That's where we're up to now. This is a war, but it comes down to the individual level as well. Members of parliament must get at least one call a week from people who are being scammed, or someone's trying scam them—all the time. So as a nation we have to be really on our guard. I believe the previous government did the best they could.

Optus and Medibank didn't want to go through the process they went through. They believed that they had armour in place so they couldn't be hacked. But somebody smarter than the person who was doing the protection was able to bypass the protection they had in place. That's what we're facing every day. So it's a whole-of-government exercise—and whole-of-community and whole-of-business. Sorry, but, to me, whacking a $1 million penalty on me is not going to make me do any better to protect my business than I would otherwise do. I will do everything to protect my business, my family and my activity. And every company is like that. I step into this space and say we've got to work together as a nation, as a people, as best we can, and we charge this government with that responsibility on behalf of the people of Australia.
